Scoping Memorandum and Ruling of Assigned Commissioner Consolidating Proceedings. Proceeding Application (A.) 19-03-023 shall be consolidated with A.18-04-023, A, 17-02-009 and A.16-03-009. The category of this consolidated proceeding is ratesetting. Administrative Law Judge Patricia B. Miles is designated as the Presiding Officer. The scope of the issues for the consolidated proceedings Application (A.) 16-03-009, A.17-02-009, A.18-04-023 shall apply to A.19-03-023. Hearings are necessary and were held with respect to Application (A.) 16-03-009 on March 6-10, 2017. The record in A.16-03-009 shall be applicable to the consolidated proceeding, which includes A.19-03-023. The remaining schedule for the consolidated proceeding is set forth in Section 4 of this ruling. The assigned Commissioner or Presiding Officer may adjust this schedule as necessary for efficient management and fair resolution of this proceeding. Parties shall adhere to the instructions provided in Section 9 of this ruling for submitting documents.

SUMMARY:  On October 3, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, and Nicolas Chaset, Chief Executive Officer of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Mr. Chaset expressed concern that no changes to the Proposed Decision (PD) or Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) had been issued to date in this proceeding. Mr. Chaset suggested that a hold be issued to delay the decision to give interested parties adequate time to respond, and that the Commission should consider allowing for a round of comments or another all-party meeting after any changes are released, given the significance of the issue and its impact on parties.

SUMMARY:  On October 3, 2018, Ms. Evelyn Kahl, Counsel, and Ms. Beth Vaughan, Executive Director, of to California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), met David M. Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, in San Francisco. Ms. Kahl observed that the determination of “indifference” rests on the valuation of the utilities’ portfolios, since Public Utilities Code §366.2(g) requires that the Commission reduce the portfolio cost by “the value of any benefits that remain with bundled service customers.” Ms. Kahl explained that the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) does not achieve indifference in valuing the bundled utility portfolios and, instead, shifts costs to departing load customers. Ms. Kahl noted that the APD’s attempt to equate the products in the utilities’ portfolios with the benchmark proxies produces a material cost shift to departing load customers. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On October 26, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel of East Bay Community Energy, met with Maria Sotero and David Gamson, advisors to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Ms. Brandt discussed the need for the brown-power true up as required by D.18-10-019 to be implemented immediately in the PCIA rate update. Ms. Brandt expressed concern that the Energy Division RA Report that will be used to determine the capacity value in the PCIA benchmark does not reflect enough of the actual market transactions, nor are updates to the report frequent enough. Ms. Brandt suggested that requirements for what the report should include and when it is released may need to be codified in a future ERRA decision since it is used to set rates in the ERRA proceeding. Ms. Brandt further raised concerns about the timing of implementation of the PCIA decision in the ERRA, and about the interpretation of details that will need to be worked out for effective implementation.

[By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, met in San Francisco with Ted Bardacke, Executive Director, and Matthew Langer, Chief Operating Officer, of CPA of Southern California Gas Company; and Denise Tyrell, Consultant, Tyrell & Associates.

column6: [By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On September 6, 2018, Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, met in San Francisco and via teleconference with representatives of Peninsula Clean Energy, City and County of San Francisco, and Sonoma Clean Power Authority.

SUMMARY:  On October 4, 2018, Neal Reardon, Director of Regulatory Affairs at Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCP), met with James Ralph and Forest Kaser, advisors to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Mr. Reardon noted that investor-owned utility shareholders should be subject to the risks and rewards of portfolio management decisions so that their incentives are aligned with those of ratepayers. Mr. Reardon emphasized the need to extract maximum value from existing contracts, and pointed to the California Community Choice Association’s voluntary buy-down and auction proposals as effective methods to achieve this.

[By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, met in San Francisco with Barbara Hale, Assistant General Manager for Power, San Francisco Public Utilities Commission; Manuel Ramirez, Manager, Planning and Regulatory Compliance, San Francisco Public Utilities Commission; and Suzy Hong, Deputy City Attorney, San Francisco City Attorney’s Office, representing the City and County of San Francisco.

SUMMARY:  On October 1, 2018, Nora Sheriff, counsel, the California Large Energy Consumers Association (CLECA), spoke by phone with Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and on October 3, 2018, Ms. Sheriff met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, and Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in two separate meetings in San Francisco, and spoke by phone with Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker. Ms. Sheriff stated that CLECA has bundled members, Direct Access members, and members who are now served by Community Choice Aggregators, as well as some members with onsite renewable generation to serve a portion of their load. Ms. Sheriff explained that with this membership, CLECA always tries to be as evenhanded as possible for purposes of how the different types of customers are treated. Ms. Sheriff told that CLECA strongly supports the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD), especially its treatment of legacy Utility Owned Generation costs.  Ms. Sheriff asked for the APD to be revised to explicitly reject the Joint Utilities’ proposal for a new, non-vintaged charge. Ms. Sheriff explained that substantial evidence in the proceeding weighs against adoption of the Joint Utilities’ proposal to change the power charge indifference adjustment allocator. Ms. Sheriff explained that if the Commission seeks consistency in allocation factors for bundled and departing customers, it should direct the filing of Rate Design Window applications on this narrow issue – which will give notice to other parties. With Mr. Gamson and Ms. Shmidt, Ms. Sheriff also noted CLECA’s recommendation that the APD be revised to allow for a de minimis valuation for unsold, excess resource adequacy and renewables portfolio standard resources that remain in the investor owned utilities’ portfolios, as opposed to a zero valuation.

column6: SUMMARY:  On September 17, 2018, the Board of Directors of the Clean Power Alliance of Southern California emailed a letter to Cmmrs. Picker, Peterman, Randolph, Guzman Aceves, and Rechtschaffen. A copy of the letter is attached to the notice.

Rechtschaffen, met in San Francisco with Lucas Frerichs, Member of the City of Davis City Council and Valley Clean Energy Alliance (VCE) Board Chair; Don Saylor, Yolo County Supervisor and VCE Board Member; Mitch Sears, VCE Interim General Manager; Lisa Limcaco, VCE Director of Finance and Operations; and Gary Lawson, VCE consultant.

SUMMARY:  On September 17, 2018, Jeanne M. Solé, Deputy Director of Power Resources, San José Clean Energy (SJCE), met with Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Lori Mitchell, Director of Community Energy, SJCE, participated by telephone. Ms. Mitchell explained that SJCE was approved unanimously by the San José City Council in May of 2017 in response to extensive community advocacy and support. Ms. Mitchell explained that San José is very concerned about providing an affordable base electricity product to its community.Ms. Solé explained that the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) would significantly jeopardize SJCE’s ability to launch its program and invest in long term renewable resources and the community through innovative customer programs. Ms. Solé stated that the APD is bad for all customers. Ms. Solé explained that the APD undermines the ability of new Community Choice Aggregators. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On September 7, 2018, Hilary Staver, Manager of Regulatory and Legislative Affairs, and Girish Balachandran, Chief Executive Officer, at Silicon Valley Clean Energy, met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. SVCE requested that the Commission adopt the Proposed Decision (PD) rather the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD). SVCE discussed potential impacts of the APD on Community Choice Aggregation customers, and highlighted several areas of disagreement with the choices made in the APD. Mr. Balachandran made the case for including a greenhouse gas-free attribute to the market price benchmark. SVCE expressed support for the capacity benchmark described in California Community Choice Association’s (CalCCA) opening testimony, but requested that the Commission at least adopt the composite capacity benchmark proposed by CalCCA in its August 21 comments on the PD. Finally, SVCE requested that the final decision adopted by the Commission include more concrete guidance on the scope and schedule for Phase 2.

column5: Direct Access Customer Coalition,Alliance for Retail Energy Markets
column6: SUMMARY:  [JOINT] On September 5, 2018, Mary Lynch, Director of Wholesale Market Development for Constellation New Energy, and Greg Bass, Western Regulatory Director for Calpine Energy Solutions, on behalf of the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM); and Cynthia Clark of the University of California and, via telephone, Michael Rochman, Managing Director of the School Project for Utility Rate Reduction, on behalf of the Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), had a meeting with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. The AReM and DACC representatives discussed the impacts that each the Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) would have on Direct Access customers and Energy Service Providers, and stated a preference for the APD. In particular, the group discussed how the applicability of the legacy utility-owned generation costs for pre-2009 Vintage DA customers is already being addressed in A.16-04-018 et al and should be determined there; that the PD’s proposed treatment of legacy utility-owned generation costs in general might have unintended consequences; the PD’s revised market price benchmarks are not well defined, would be problematic, and that the use of the Renewable Energy Credit market index would be simpler, more accurate, more transparent and more predicable than the proposed RPS Adder. Further, the group expressed concern about the percent-based PCIA collar and discontinuation of the 10-year cost recovery rule that are proposed in the APD.

SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel and Nicolas Chaset, CEO, of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and with James Ralph and Forest Kaser, advisors to Cmmr. Picker, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. At the second meeting, also present was Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division. The discussion concerned the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) and EBCE’s perspective on the Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternate Proposed Decision (APD).  EBCE representatives pointed out that the utility narrative that bundled customers are bearing a significant cost shift under the current PCIA methodology is flawed; PG&E’s 2019 ERRA filing (A.18-06-001) shows bundled customer rates substantially declining and the PCIA for departed load customers going up significantly. EBCE representatives explained that the APD differs from the PD in material ways that would have catastrophic consequences for CCAs, and where the PD balanced changes that would benefit utilities with those that benefit CCAs, the APD makes changes that solely benefit utilities. EBCE representatives noted that both the PD and the APD create a cost shift onto CCAs by making the wrong changes to the capacity benchmark price. EBCE representatives explained that the APD will hinder achievement of the state’s energy goals. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On September 4, 2018, Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to, and Beth Vaughan, Executive Director of, California Community Choice Association (CalCCA) had a telephone conversation with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker. CalCCA representatives discussed Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternative Proposed Decision (APD) in this proceeding. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On September 4, 2018, Neal Reardon, Director of Regulatory Affairs at the Sonoma Clean Power Authority (“SCP”), met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. SCP addressed the potential impact of the Alternate Proposed Decision on their customers and business model. Mr. Reardon noted that the rate tables PG&E provided on 8/31 contained errors which had not yet been addressed. Mr. Reardon highlighted the impact of a rising PCIA coupled with declining bundled rates on CCA competitiveness. SCP requested that the PD, not APD, be adopted. Finally, Mr. Reardon cited CPUC data showing that PG&E’s RPS procurement costs have risen over the 2011-2016 timeframe, while the market price benchmark for renewables has declined over that time period. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On September 19, 2018, Ms. Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to, and Ms. Beth Vaughan, Executive Director of, California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman at the Commission offices. Ms. Kahl and Ms. Vaughan advocated the modification of the capacity benchmark, greenhouse gas benchmark and true-up mechanism consistent with CalCCA’s proposals.

SUMMARY:  On September 18, 2018, Laura Genao, Managing Director of Regulatory Affairs of Southern California Edison Company (SCE); and Erik Jacobson, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Fong Wan, Senior Vice President of Energy Policy and Procurement, of Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Carla Peterman, in San Francisco.  Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Kendall Helm, Vice President of Energy Procurement of San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), and Colin Cushnie, Vice President of Energy Procurement and Management of SCE, participated via telephone.  SCE’s PG&E’s, and SDG&E’s (collectively, Joint Utilities) representatives discussed five major issues: (1) the APD’s current PCIA “cost cap” and “collars;” (2) the APD’s PCIA market price benchmarks; (3) the Joint Utilities’ non-vintaging proposal; (4) the APD’s PCIA pre-payment provision; and (5) the need for additional clarity in the APD for the PCIA “true-up” mechanism. The Joint Utilities urged the Commission to adopt the APD with the modifications that the Joint Utilities have proposed, in order to ensure bundled service customer indifference. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

column5: Peninsula Clean Energy Authority, City and County of San Francisco, and Sonoma Clean Power Authority
column6: SUMMARY:  On September 6, 2018, Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer, Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, Dave Pine, President of the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors and Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE) Board Member, and Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, on behalf of PCE, the City and County of San Francisco (CCSF), and Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCPA), met with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Martha Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. James Hendry, Regulatory and Legislative Affairs, Power Enterprise for the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission (operator of CleanPowerSF), and Neal Reardon, Director of Regulatory Affairs for SCPA, also participated on behalf of CCSF and SCPA, respectively. Mr. Hendry attended the meeting in person and Mr. Reardon attended by phone. PCE, CCSF, and SCPA representatives discussed the Proposed Decision of Administrative Law Judge Roscow (PD) and the August 14, 2018 Alternate Proposed Decision of Commissioner Peterman (APD). Ms. Pepper stated that a reasonable approach based on the record is to set the PCIA at the level contemplated by the PD or even maintain the PCIA at the current level until the second phase of the PCIA proceeding is completed. Mr. Waen discussed his experience working on PCIA issues over the course of his work with CCAs. Mr. Wiedman discussed support in the record for setting the benchmarks in a more reasonable fashion than either the APD or PD currently does and how the record supports the PD’s approach to the PCIA. Mr. Pine discussed the strong support for PCE within San Mateo County. Mr. Reardon discussed the impacts of the PCIA to SCPA’s residential customers while also noting that the rate tables PG&E provided on 8/31 contained errors which had not yet been addressed. Mr. Hendry commented that the PD/APD’s proposed value for capacity not only represents the low-range of values identified in the record of the proceeding but also represents the low range of the environmental attributes of the generation. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Cal PA representatives expressed its support for Commissioner Peterman’s Alternate Proposed Decision over the Proposed Decision and offered additional recommendations. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

column5: City and County of San Francisco
column6: SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, Barbara Hale, Assistant General Manager for Power, and Manuel Ramirez, Manager, Planning and Regulatory Compliance, for San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Suzy Hong, Deputy City Attorney, San Francisco City Attorney’s Office, the City and County of San Francisco (San Francisco) was also present. Ms. Hale described San Francisco’s Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) program, CleanPowerSF, and the potential impacts on CleanPowerSF of the Proposed Decision (PD) and the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD). Ms. Hale discussed how San Francisco believes that the PD provides a reasonable transition to the longer-term solutions proposed for Phase 2 of this proceeding. Ms. Hale explained concerns with the APD and its potential negative impacts on CleanPowerSF’s program. Ms. Hale highlighted how these impacts would hinder San Francisco’s ability to meet the City’s and the state’s environmental goals. Ms. Hale and Mr. Ramirez discussed San Francisco’s positions on the PD’s and APD’s treatment of issues regarding pre-2002 legacy utility-owned generation (UOG), the 10-year limit on cost recovery for post-2002 non-RPS UOG resources, the value for the capacity benchmark in the PCIA calculation, and a PCIA rate cap and collar. Ms. Hale and Mr. Ramirez noted San Franciso’s support of the positions of the California Community Choice Association on these issues. With respect to legacy UOG and the 10-year limit on cost recovery for post-2002 resources, Ms. Hale emphasized the need to provide incentive to investor-owned utilities (IOUs) to prudently manage their portfolios and resources. Ms. Hale questioned why IOUs should be allowed to recover from customers the uneconomic operating costs of resources owned by the IOUs.

Notice of Ex Parte Communication. Solana Energy Alliance reports an ex parte communication with Yuliya Shmidt, Advisor to Commissioner Rechtschaffen on September 7, 2018 from approximately 1:00 pm to 1:30 pm.

SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, Lucas Frerichs, member of the City of Davis City Council and Valley Clean Energy Alliance (VCE), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in four separate meetings in San Francisco. At the meeting with John Reynolds also present was Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division. Don Saylor, Yolo County Supervisor and VCE Board Member, Mitch Sears, VCE Interim General Manager, Lisa Limcaco, VCE Director of Finance and Operations, and Gary Lawson, VCE consultant were present at the meetings. VCE representatives discussed the fact that VCE is the only Central Valley’s community choice aggregator (CCA). VCE representatives stated its support of California Community Choice Association’s comments in this proceeding, and explained that it prefers the proposed decision of ALJ Roscow to the alternate proposed decision of Cmmr. Peterman. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018 Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer, Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst of Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE), and Jeff Aalfs, Portola Valley Town Councilmember, met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. At the meeting with Forest Kaser also present was Mitchell Shapson, Staff Attorney with the Legal Division. Ms. Pepper explained the impacts of the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) and Proposed Decision (PD) on PCE and that a reasonable approach based on the record is to set the PCIA at the level contemplated by the PD or even maintain the PCIA at the current level until the second phase of the PCIA proceeding is completed. Ms. Pepper explained that uncertainty created by the true-up and collar contemplated in the APD would incentivize CCAs to transact in the shorter term markets — a result which is neither aligned with PCE’s goals nor consistent with state policies. Mr. Waen discussed his experience working on PCIA issues. Mr. Wiedman discussed support in the record for setting the benchmarks in a more reasonable fashion than either the APD or PD currently do and how the record supports the PD’s approach to the PCIA. Mr. Aalfs discussed PCE’s goals to drive decarbonization and support innovation in the energy sector and how those goals relate to the ongoing PCIA discussion. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

column5: Clean Power Alliance of Southern California
column6: SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, Ted Bardacke, Executive Director of the Clean Power Alliance of Southern California (CPA), had a teleconference with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves. Matthew Langer, Chief Operating Officer of CPA, and Denise Tyrell, Consultant, Tyrell & Associates, also participated in the conference. Messrs. Bardacke and Langer and Ms. Tyrell discussed the written material attached to this notice.

SUMMARY:  On September 4, 2018, Nathaniel Malcolm, Policy Counsel, Shalini Swaroop, Director of Regulatory and Legislative Policy, and Dawn Weisz, Chief Executive Officer, of Marin Clean Energy (MCE ), and Kevin Haroff, MCE Board Member and City Councilmember from the City of Larkspur, met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in three separate meetings in San Francisco. At the meeting with John Reynolds also present was Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division. MCE representatives discussed the Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternate Proposed Decision (APD). Councilmember Haroff described his historical experience with the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA). Ms. Weisz addressed the APD’s potential effects on MCE’s procurement and programmatic activities. Ms. Weisz further emphasized avoidable costs that should not be allocated to CCA customers. MCE requested that the Commission retain many of the PD’s determinations, including its determinations on Legacy Utility Owned Generation (UOG), the 10-year limit on cost recovery for post-2002 UOG, and the cap and collar approach. MCE urged the Commission to adjust the proposed benchmarks, clarify the true-up process, and remove from the PCIA avoidable costs resulting from portfolio mismanagement, including those costs caused by PG&E’s failure to forecast and account for MCE’s departure in 2010. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On September 4, 2018, Mea Halperin, Senior Regulatory Analyst, Radu Ciupagea, Program & Project Supervisor; and Candace Choe, attorney for, the Public Advocates Office (Cal PA), participated in an oral ex parte communication with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco. Cal PA expressed support for Commissioner Peterman’s Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) over the Proposed Decision (PD) and offered additional recommendations. Specifically, Ms. Halperin discussed aspects of the APD that are improvements over the PD. However, Cal PA opposes allowing Community Choice Aggregator and Direct Access providers to pre-pay their PCIA obligation. Referring to the greater rate impacts of the APD, Cal PA agreed to consider those rate impacts but suggested that the Commission’s decision should be driven by whichever methodology achieves indifference. Cal PA stated its general opposition to imposing a collar which is included in both the PD. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.
OPENING COMMENTS ON THE ALTERNATE PROPOSED DECISION

SUMMARY:  On September 4, 2018, Alicia Priego, consultant, Lori Mitchell, Director of Community Energy, and Jeanne Solé, Deputy Director of Power Resources, of San José Clean Energy (SJCE), met in San Francisco with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division, and on September 5, 2018, with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen Ms. Mitchell explained that San José is very concerned about providing an affordable base electricity product to its community. Ms. Solé explained that the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) would significantly jeopardize SJCE’s ability to launch its program and invest in long term renewable resources and the community through innovative customer programs. Ms. Solé explained that the APD is bad for all customers. Ms. Solé noted that the APD is not needed since PG&E’s rates are already going down. Ms. Solé explained that the APD undermines the ability of new CCAs to launch. Additionally, and only during the meeting with Yulia Shmidt, Ms. Solé explained that if 2002 utility-owned generation (UOG) are not excluded, it is all the more important to recognize the value of GHG-free resources. Ms. Solé also explained that it is critical to reflect the long-term value of capacity since the short-term market value of capacity in California is artificially depressed due to long-term planning. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.
COMMENTS ON THE ALTERNATE PROPOSED DECISION

[By Decisionmaker]  SUMMARY:  On August 13, 2018, David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, met in San Francisco with Mary Lynch, Director Wholesale Market Development for Constellation NewEnergy, Scott Olson, Director of Western Government and Regulatory Affairs for Direct Energy, and Greg Bass, Western Regulatory Director for Calpine Energy Solutions, on behalf of the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM); and Cynthia Clark of the University of California, Robert Ule of Viavi Solutions and Michael Rochman, Managing Director for School Project for Utility Rate Reduction, on behalf of the Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC). Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC, was also present.

SUMMARY:  On August 24, 2018, Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer of Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present were Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, and Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, for PSE; Dave Pine, San Mateo County Board of Supervisors; Jeff Aalfs, Portola Valley Town Councilmember; and Pradeep Gupta, South San Francisco City Councilmember. Ms. Pepper discussed the impacts of the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) and Proposed Decision (PD) on PCE and that a reasonable approach based on the record is to freeze the PCIA at current levels to avoid cost shifts in either direction until the second phase of the PCIA proceeding is completed. Mr. Waen provided examples of certain electricity and capacity generating resources that clearly have value beyond what would be reflected within the proposed benchmarks within either the APD or PD. Mr. Wiedman discussed support in the record for setting the benchmarks in a more reasonable fashion than either the APD or PD currently do. Mr. Gupta discussed how economics underlying energy policy are shifting from utilization of natural gas facilities to renewables and how that impacts traditional ratemaking concepts in the PCIA context. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On August 24, 2018, Geof Syphers, Chief Executive Officer of the Sonoma Clean Power Authority, sent a letter to Cmmrs. Picker, Cmmrs. Guzman Aceves, Peterman, Randolph, and Rechtshaffen. A copy of the letter is attached to the notice.

SUMMARY:  On August 22, 2018, Laura Genao, Managing Director of Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and John Reynolds, Advisor to Commissioner Carla Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present were Ranbir Sekhon, Director of Portfolio Planning and Analysis, for SCE; Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Emily Shults, Vice President of Electric and Fuel Procurement, for San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E); and Erik Jacobson, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Fong Wan, Senior Vice President of Energy Policy and Procurement, for Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) (collectively, Joint Utilities). The Joint Utilities representatives discussed how the current Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) and Proposed Decision – if not modified – do not ensure bundled service customer indifference, as required by California statute. The Joint Utilities stressed that the net costs of Utility-Owned Generation and mandated procurement must be shared equitably by all customers. The Joint Utilities emphasized the need for additional clarity in the APD for the PCIA “true-up” mechanism. Finally, the Joint Utilities discussed how the hedging costs that are associated with short-term market purchases are not included in the PCIA. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 21, 2018, Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to the California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also in attendance were Mitchell Shapson, CPUC legal counsel, and Beth Vaughan, Executive Director of CalCCA. Ms. Kahl and Ms. Vaughan discussed the written material attached to the notice, cautioning that some of the materials reflect only a preliminary evaluation.

SUMMARY:  On August 21, 2018, Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to the California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also in attendance was Beth Vaughan, CalCCA’s Executive Director. Ms. Kahl and Ms. Vaughan discussed the written material, cautioning that some of the materials reflect only a preliminary evaluation. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 21, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel for East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), had a telephone communication with Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and on August 23, 2018, met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel for EBCE participated in the telephone communication and in the meeting. At the meeting with David Peck also present was Nicolas Chaset, CEO for EBCE.  EBCE stated that the Proposed Decision (PD) provides a reasonable interim solution to issues with the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) while the Commission resolves remaining issues in Phase II of the PCIA. EBCE stated that it supports the PD’s legal conclusion that pre-2002 legacy utility-owned generation (UOG) costs may not be included in the PCIA for Community Choice Aggregator (CCA) customers. EBCE stated its support for the PD’s provision for a “cap/collar” to mitigate the impact of changes in the PCIA. EBCE indicated its concerns with several aspects of the PD. EBCE recommended reforms to the capacity benchmark and the greenhouse gas free price; the cap/collar mechanism recommended in the PD in Phase I would serve as a bridge to keeping parties cost-neutral until we get through Phase II.

SUMMARY:  On August 18, 2018, Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to the California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), had a telephone conference with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. Ms. Kahl discussed the written material, cautioning that some of the materials reflect only a preliminary evaluation. A copy of the written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 22, 2018, Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer, Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, and Rick Bonilla, Mayor of San Mateo. Jan Pepper discussed the impacts of the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) and Proposed Decision (PD) on PCE and that a reasonable approach based on the record is to freeze the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) at current levels to avoid cost shifts in either direction until the second phase of the PCIA proceeding is completed. Mr. Bonilla discussed the broader context of PCE’s efforts to combat climate change. Mr. Waen discussed the long-term advocacy by the large investor-owned utilities (IOUs) regarding PCIA, pointing out that the APD gives the IOUs what they were arguing for on the PCIA prior to their development of the Portfolio Allocation Mechanism. Mr. Wiedman discussed support in the record for setting the benchmarks in a more reasonable fashion than either the APD or the PD currently do and how the record supports a freeze on the PCIA until Phase 2 actions are underway.

SUMMARY:  On August 20, 2018, Catherine Blakespear, Mayor of the City of Encinitas (the City), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman at the Commission offices.  Catherine Blakespear discussed the City’s commitment to establishing a Community Choice Energy (CCE) program and the impact of the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment in determining the feasibility of the CCE.

SUMMARY:  On August 20, 2018, Catherine Blakespear, Mayor of the City of Encinitas (the City), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and Mitchell Shapson, attorney with the Legal Division, at the Commission offices.  Catherine Blakespear discussed the City’s commitment to establishing a Community Choice Energy (CCE) program and the impact of the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment in determining the feasibility of the CCE.

column5: Direct Access Customer Coalition,Alliance for Retail Energy Markets
column6: [Joint] SUMMARY:  On August 15, 2018, Mary Lynch, Director of Wholesale Market Development for Constellation NewEnergy, and Scott Olson, Director of Western Government and Regulatory Affairs for Direct Energy, representing the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM) had a telephone conversation with Joanne Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. Cynthia Clark of the University of California and Michael Rochman, Managing Director for School Project for Utility Rate Reduction (SPURR), representing Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), and Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC also participated in the communication. AReM and DACC representatives discussed the impact the August 1 Proposed Decision (PD) and the August 15 Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) would have on Direct Access customers and Energy Service Providers. The AReM and DACC representatives discussed how the applicability of the legacy utility-owned generation costs for pre-2009 Vintage DA customers is already being addressed in A.16-04-011et al and should be determined there; that the PD’s proposed treatment of legacy utility-owned generation costs in general might have unintended consequences; the PD’s and APD’s revised market price benchmarks are not well defined, and that the use of the Renewable Energy Credit market index would be simpler, more accurate, more transparent and more predicable that the proposed RPS Adder. AReM and DACC representatives discussed the challenges the Commission would face in attempting to true-up the RPS and RA adders.

SUMMARY:  On August 14, 2018, Megan Somogyi, counsel for Commercial Energy of California (Commercial Energy), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in two separate meetings; and on April 15, 2018, with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves. All meetings were held in San Francisco. At the meetings with John Reynolds and James Ralph also present was Patrick Vanbeek, Vice President of Operations of Commercial Energy. Commercial Energy indicated its support for the concept in the Proposed Decision (PD) to commence a second phase of the case; however, Commercial Energy recommended that the Commission needs to provide the parties with both more specific guidance on the type of mechanism to be discussed and a limited time frame for the discussions. Commercial Energy recommended that the Commission ensure that RECs and RA attributes from the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) resources can be transferred to the LSEs. Commercial Energy also addressed the PCIA cap and collar established by the PD. Commercial Energy stated that the cap and annual maximum rate adjustment are too low. During the meetings with Mr. Ralph and Mr. Gamson, Ms. Somogyi stated that Commercial Energy favors the more flexible rate collar proposed in the Alternate PD. In the meetings with Mr. Reynolds and Mr. Ralph, Ms. Somogyi and Mr. Vanbeek discussed the new reporting requirements for ESPs established by the PD that would require ESPs to provide granular and highly sensitive contract information to the Commission to inform the RPS and RA benchmarks. Commercial Energy indicated that it is not aware of a statutory or other basis on which the Commission can require ESPs to divulge sensitive contract price information, and Commercial Energy believes that available market price indices can be used in lieu of ESP contract price data. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On August 8, 2018, Laura Genao, Managing Director of Regulatory Affairs of Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Colin Cushnie, Vice President of Energy Procurement and Management of SCE; Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Emily Shults, Vice President of Electric and Fuel Procurement, of San Diego Gas & Electric Company; Erik Jacobson, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Fong Wan, Senior Vice President of Energy Policy and Procurement of Pacific Gas and Electric Company; Colin Cushnie, Vice President of Energy Procurement and Management of SCE (collectively called “Joint Utilities Representatives”).  Joint Utilities Representatives discussed three major issues: (1) The Proposed Decision’s (PD) current treatment of Utility-Owned Generation (UOG) and energy storage resources; (2) the PD’s current PCIA “cost cap;” and (3) the PD’s PCIA “true-up” mechanism. Joint Utilities discussed how the current PD – if not modified – does not ensure bundled service customer indifference, as required by California statute. Joint Utilities Representatives discussed how the current PCIA “cost cap” is unreasonable and not equitable for bundled service customers. Joint Utilities explained the historical ratemaking treatment of UOG resources. Joint Utilities Representatives emphasized the need for additional clarity in the PD for the PCIA “true-up” mechanism. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 29, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, and Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel for East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), met in San Francisco with Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and on August 30, 2018, with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman. Ms. Brandt and Mr. Edmister explained that the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) differs from the Proposed Decision (PD) in material ways that would have catastrophic consequences for Community Choice Aggregators (CCAs). Ms. Brandt and Mr. Edmister further noted EBCE’s concerns with the capacity valuation approach taken in both the PD and the APD. Ms. Brandt and Mr. Edmister stated that the APD will force numerous CCAs to at minimum fundamentally change their procurement practices, or at worst go out of business, the APD will do so by illegally and unfairly shifting costs from bundled to CCA customers. Brandt and Mr. Edmister discussed changes to the APD. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 27, 2018, Megan Somogyi, counsel for Commercial Energy of California (Commercial Energy), met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco. Ms. Somogyi indicated that Commercial Energy supported the concept in the Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) to commence a second phase of the case with a working group of parties to consider a longer-term change to the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) mechanism. Ms. Somogyi recommended that the Commission provide the parties with both more specific guidance on the type of mechanism to be discussed and a limited time frame for the discussions. Commercial Energy recommends that the PD be modified to detail principles to guide the working group discussion. Commercial Energy also recommends that the Commission ensure that RECs and RA attributes from the PCIA resources can be transferred to the LSEs that will acquire the resources via allocation or auction. Ms. Somogyi stated that Commercial Energy believes the cap and annual maximum rate adjustment in the PD are too low. Ms. Somogyi stated that Commercial Energy favors the more flexible rate collar proposed in the APD. Ms. Somogyi expressed concern that the new reporting requirements for ESPs established by the PD and APD that would require ESPs to provide granular and highly sensitive contract information to the Commission. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

column5: Direct Access Customer Coalition,Alliance for Retail Energy Markets
column6: [Joint] SUMMARY:  On August 23, 2018, Greg Bass, Director, Western Regulatory & Legislative Affairs for Calpine Energy Solutions, on behalf of the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Cynthia Clark of the University of California, on behalf of the Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC); and Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC; and Mary Lynch, Director Wholesale Market Development for Constellation NewEnergy, and Dan Douglass, counsel to AReM and DACC, joined telephonically. The AReM and DACC representatives discussed the impact the Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) would have on Direct Access customers and Energy Service Providers and stated a preference for the APD while noting appreciation for both decisions. The AReM and DACC representatives discussed the applicability of the legacy utility-owned generation costs to pre-2009 Vintage DA customers. The AReM and DACC representatives expressed concern that the PD’s and APD’s revised market price benchmarks are not well defined, and that the use of the Renewable Energy Credit market index would be simpler, more accurate, more transparent and more predicable that the proposed RPS Adder. Further, AReM/DACC questioned the legal authority of the Commission to divulge sensitive and confidential contract information but that if such information is to be provided it must be accorded meaningful confidentiality protections The AReM and DACC representatives discussed the challenges the Commission would face in attempting to true-up the RPS and RA adders.

[By Decisionmaker]  SUMMARY:  On August 13, 2018, John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, met in San Francisco with Mary Lynch, Director Wholesale Market Development for Constellation NewEnergy; Scott Olson, Director of Western Government and Regulatory Affairs for Direct Energy, and Greg Bass, Western Regulatory Director for Calpine Energy Solutions, on behalf of the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM); Cynthia Clark of the University of California, Robert Ule of Viavi Solutions and Michael Rochman, Managing Director for School Project for Utility Rate Reduction, on behalf of the Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC); and Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC.

SUMMARY:  [LATE FILED] On May 21, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Director of Regulatory & Legislative Affairs and Deputy General Counsel for East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), met in San Francisco with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker; on May 24, 2018, with Rachel Peterson and Joanna Gubman, advisors to Cmmr. Randolph; and on June 8, 2018, with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen. Ms. Brandt provided EBCE’s perspective as a newer community choice aggregator (CCA). Ms. Brandt stated that the joint utilities’ GAM/PMM proposal does not adequately meet EBCE’s needs. Ms. Brandt explained that the joint utility proposal would force CCAs to buy the majority of their supply in the short-term market, since that is when supply would be made available to CCAs and the joint utility proposal does not guarantee delivery quantities. Ms. Brandt emphasized that it is important for the CPUC to provide stability to the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) framework in the short-term as it transitions to an equitable longer-term solution.  On August 10, 2018, Ms. Brandt had a telephone conversation with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and had two separate meetings in San Francisco with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves. At the meeting with David Gamson also present were Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to CalCCA and Beth Vaughan, Executive Director for CalCCA. Ms. Brandt reiterated the legal and policy rationales that support the PD’s removing legacy utility-owned generation from the PCIA calculation. Ms. Brandt expressed concerns with the PD’s proposed true-up mechanism. During the meeting with David Gamson, written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On August 15, 2018, Laura Genao, Managing Director of Regulatory Affairs of Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division, and with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present were Colin Cushnie, Vice President of Energy Procurement and Management for SCE; Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Emily Shults, Vice President of Electric and Fuel Procurement, for San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E); and Erik Jacobson, Director of Regulatory Affairs, and Fong Wan, Senior Vice President of Energy Policy and Procurement, for Pacific Gas and Electric Company (collectively, the Joint Utilities). The Joint Utilities representatives discussed how the current Alternative Proposed Decision (APD) and PD – if not modified – do not ensure bundled service customer indifference, as required by California statute. The Joint Utilities discussed how the current PCIA “cost cap” is unreasonable, constitutes legal error, and is not equitable for bundled service customers, especially as set forth in the PD. The Joint Utilities stressed that the net costs of Utility-Owned Generation and mandated procurement must be shared equitably by all customers, and emphasized the need for additional clarity in the APD for the PCIA “true-up” mechanism, especially as it would apply to excess Renewable Energy Credits that the Joint Utilities were unable to sell. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 15, 2018, Bill Powers, technical consultant, and Stephanie Stadfi, outside counsel, to Protect Our Communities Foundation (POC), met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Michael Picker, in San Francisco. Jamie Pang, staff counsel to POC, participated by telephone. On August 16, 2018, Bill Powers, Jamie Pang, and Stephanie Stadfi participated in a conference call with Mark Smith, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and on August 17, 2018, with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves. POC representatives addressed the alternative proposed decision (APD) released on August 14, 2018. POC expressed general support for the PD and opposition to the APD’s inclusion of legacy UOG in the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA). POC expressed opposition to the APD’s termination of the 10-year limit on utility cost recovery and reiterated the need for a 10-year limit to motivate utilities to account for realistic load departure in their forecasts. POC also expressed opposition to the APD for its failure to maintain the $0.022/kWh collar on the PCIA. POC expressed the opinion that utility concerns about rising above market solar and wind contract costs in future years should be addressed through securitization of existing solar and wind contracts. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Alternate Proposed Decision of Commissioner Peterman modifying the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment Methodology.  Proposed Decision modifying the Power Indifference Adjustment Methodology. 

PER ALJ ROSCOW, VIA HIS EMAIL RULING SENT ON 9/4/18:  

(1) The deadline for comments on the APD is changed to September 6, 2018 at 5 p.m.
(2) The deadline for consolidated reply comments on the PD and the APD is changed to September 11, 2018 at 5 p.m.

Page limits:

(3) Parties may submit a total, for both the PD and APD combined, of 40 pages of comments.
(4) Parties may submit a total of 10 pages of reply comments.

SUMMARY:  On August 9, 2018, Powers, technical consultant, and Jamie Pang, staff counsel, Protect Our Communities Foundation (POC), met with Yulia Schmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen and John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings, and on August 10, 2018, with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. At the meeting with Yulia Schmidt also present was Laura Martin of the Energy Division. POC representatives advocated that the $0.022/kilowatt hour per year cap on the power charge indifference adjustment (PCIA) should be a hard cap with no upward adjustment year-to-year. POC pointed-out that had the proposed decision (PD) disallowed avoidable solar and wind contract costs, in the specific case of SDG&E the (residential) PCIA would be approximately half the $0.021/kWh projected by the utility for 2018. POC noted that utility projections under current utility PCIA above-market calculation procedures indicate 2018 PCIA above market costs are at or near peak costs and these costs will decline going forward. POC expressed the opinion that utility concerns about rising above market solar and wind contract costs in future years should be addressed through securitization of existing solar and wind contracts, and not by allowing the PCIA cap to increase by as much as $0.005/kWh per year as currently proposed in the PD. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On August 10, 2018, Evelyn Kahl, Counsel to the California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), met with David Gamson, advisor Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, at the Commission’s offices. Also in attendance were Beth Vaughan, CalCCA’s Executive Director, and Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel for East Bay Community Energy. Ms. Kahl, Ms. Vaughan and Ms. Brandt discussed the written material, cautioning that some of the materials reflect only a preliminary evaluation. A copy of the written materials (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On June 28, 2018, Evelyn Kahl, counsel for California Community Choice Association (CalCCA) had a communication by WebEx and telephone with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. Beth Vaughan, Executive Director, and Mr. Aldyn Hoekstra, consultant, for CalCCA, also participated in the communication. The CalCCA team highlighted the need for a comprehensive solution to the stranded cost problem and summarizing the three elements of CalCCA’s proposal. Ms. Kahl also summarized the flaws with the Joint Utilities’ GAM/PMM proposal. Mr. Hoekstra responded to the Joint Utilities’ criticism of administrative benchmarks and their proposed use of actual market “receipts” to value the portfolio under the GAM/PMM. Ms. Kahl concluded that CalCCA’s proposal offers an easily implementable transition to a long-term, durable solution. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.
THREE-DAY ADVANCE NOTICE OF EX PARTE COMMUNICATION

SUMMARY:  On June 21, 2018, Ron Perry, President and Chief Executive Officer of Commercial Energy of California (Commercial Energy), met with Ms. Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco. Also present was Michael Day, counsel for Commercial Energy. Mr. Day and Mr. Perry explained the Commercial Energy proposal entitled "Voluntary Allocation & Auction Clearinghouse" (VAAC), and the participants and methodology for conducting the allocation and then an auction of remaining utility Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA)-eligible resources. Mr. Perry explained that this model is based upon the successful allocation and auction procedure adopted by the Commission. Mr. Day and Mr. Perry explained that the VAAC auction would fix the cost of the winning bidder's portion of a generation pool, and at the same time fix the remaining PCIA costs associated with that resource. Mr. Day and Mr. Perry indicated that the Commission should combine useful recommendations from several parties in order to produce a comprehensive solution in the proceeding, including implementation of the VAAC allocation and auction procedures, together with the adoption of a residual PCIA recovery charge much like the final stage of the utilities' Portfolio Monetization Mechanism. Written material (attached to the notice) was used. In addition, on June 22, 2018, Mr. Day provided by electronic mail a cite to the Commission decision which adopted the PG&E/CTA allocation and auction process. A copy of the e-mail is provided in the body of the notice.

SUMMARY:  On June 20, 2018, Cody Hooven, Program Manager for the City of San Diego (CSD) met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Mitchell Shapson, Staff Attorney, in San Francisco. Also present were Jack Clark, Deputy Director of Environmental Services, and Frederick Ortlieb, counsel, for CSD. Ms. Hooven discussed CSD’s Climate Action Plan and the City’s interest in continuing to assess the feasibility of commencing Community Choice Aggregation or another program in San Diego which could allow for increasing supply of renewable energy in the City. Ms. Hooven emphasized the importance to CSD of maintaining the viability of customer choice in San Diego. Mr. Clark and Mr. Ortlieb discussed positions taken by the City in its opening brief in this proceeding as well as positions taken by other parties in reply briefs. CSD representatives also discussed the limited information in the record about potential rate impacts that the Green Allocation Mechanism / Portfolio Monetization Mechanism proposal might have relative to departing load and bundled customers in the SDG&E area.

column5: Marin Clean Energy,Sonoma Clean Power Authority
column6: [Joint] SUMMARY:  On June 18, 2018, Neal Reardon, Director of Regulatory Affairs, Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCPA), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Mitchell Shapson, Attorney, CPUC, and Nathaniel Malcolm, Policy Counsel, Marin Clean Energy (MCE). MCE and SCPA argued that the Joint Utilities’ Green Allocation Mechanism (GAM) violates statute by allocating products instead of costs to Community Choice Aggregators (CCA).  MCE and SCPA emphasized they are already positioned to meet their respective long-term Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) requirements and are projected to meet and exceed RPS requirements through 2030 without GAM allocations. MCE and SCPA also indicated that forcing MCE and SCPA to be excessively long on RPS would potentially bring Pacific Gas and Electric Company and Southern California Edison Company well under RPS compliance. In this context, MCE and SCPA addressed the California Community Choice Association’s voluntary Staggered Portfolio Auction (SPA) as a way for all Load Serving Entities to acquire the RPS resources needed to serve their forecasted loads and meet, or voluntarily exceed RPS requirements. MCE and SCPA also noted that the GAM, unlike the SPA, would not provide CCAs the underlying energy associated with the allocated GAM Renewable Energy Credits. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On July 5 and 6, 2018, Cathy DeFalco, Operations Director, and Scott Blaising, regulatory counsel, for the California Choice Energy Authority (CCEA) had several separate telephone conferences, as follows: on July 5, 2018, with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman; and on July 6, 2018, with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker. CCEA discussed the Proposed Decision of ALJ Roscow Resolving Track 1 Issues In The Service Territories Of Southern California Edison Company And San Diego Gas & Electric Company (PD), issued on June 6, 2018. Ms. DeFalco provided a brief description of the CCEA members: the cities of Lancaster, Pico Rivera, Rancho Mirage and San Jacinto. Ms. DeFalco noted that, with the exception of Rancho Mirage, each of the CCEA members serves residential customers comprised of over 40 percent participation in either or both the California Alternate Rates for Energy (CARE) and Medical Baseline (MB) programs. Ms. DeFalco noted that CARE customers are currently eligible for a discount on the monthly flat fee to participate in Lancaster Choice Energy’s 100 percent renewable energy program. Mr. Blaising expressed concern with respect to four aspects of the PD.

Randolph. Nathaniel Malcolm, Policy Counsel, Marin Clean Energy (MCE), also participated in the communication. MCE and SCPA argued that the Joint Utilities’ Green Allocation Mechanism (GAM) violates statute by allocating products instead of costs to Community Choice Aggregators (CCA).  MCE and SCPA addressed the California Community Choice Association’s voluntary Staggered Portfolio Auction (SPA) as a way for all Load Serving Entities to acquire the RPS resources needed to serve their forecasted loads and meet, or voluntarily exceed RPS requirements. MCE and SCPA indicated that forcing MCE and SCPA to be excessively long on RPS would potentially bring Pacific Gas and Electric Company and Southern California Edison Company well under RPS compliance. SUMMARY:  On June 20, 2018, Ty Tosdal, regulatory counsel for Solana Energy Alliance (SEA), met with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Mitchell Shapson, Staff Attorney, in San Francisco.  Also present were Greg Wade, City Manager of the City of Solana Beach (City) and Executive Director of SEA; and Dan King, Assistant City Manager of the City. Mr. Wade described Solana Beach’s efforts to develop a Community Choice Aggregation program in the City. Mr. Wade stated that SEA officially launched on June 1, 2018. Mr. Wade explained that the approval of the Green Allocation Mechanism (GAM) and the Portfolio Monetization Mechanism (PMM), proposed by the Investor Owned Utilities , would cause such a detriment to SEA that the program may be forced to close, upending the expectations of the citizens of Solana Beach and frustrating the efforts of the City to address climate change. From SEA’s perspective, Mr. Tosdal explained, the existing Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) framework, subject to modification, is the preferred option, and CalCCA’s proposals to bring down IOU portfolio costs that contribute to the PCIA – securitization and reverse auction – should be adopted. Mr. Tosdal also discussed SEA’s particular concerns about implementation.

column5: Direct Access Customer Coalition,Alliance for Retail Energy Markets
column6: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On April 30, 2018, Mary Lynch of Constellation NewEnergy and Scott Olson of Direct Energy, representatives from the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), met with Mitchell Shapson, Staff Attorney and John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Cynthia Clark of the University of California, George Waidelich of Albertsons and Chris Hendrix of Walmart representing Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC, and Dan Douglass, counsel to AReM and DACC, attended telephonically. Mr. Olson and Ms. Lynch explained that the allocation of Renewable Energy Credits and Resource Adequacy through the utilities’ GAM approach does not meet what other load-serving entities want and need. Mr. Fulmer described the elements of his testimony. Mr. Waidelich explained that DA customers desire energy cost stability and predictability and that the biggest impediment is the volatility and unpredictability of Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA). Mr. Waidelich recommended that the Commission should allow DA customers to pre-pay their PCIA obligation, based on a mutually acceptable forecast of that customer’s future PCIA obligation. Mr. Hendrix discussed the AReM/DACC proposal that the Commission should institute a cap on the PCIA. Mr. Fulmer clarified that there is already a “floor” in place and that adding a cap would create a “collar” where exposure of DA and bundled customers to volatility is more symmetric. Ms. Clark noted that DA customers in the current pre-2009 vintage tranche that have paid their stranded cost obligations should be permanently exempted from any PCIA or successor tariff.

Summary:  on February 12, 2018, Evelyn Kahl of Alcantar & Kahl, counsel to the California Community Choice Association (CalCCA) had communication via teleconference with John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman.  Beth Vaughan, Executive Director of CalCCA, also participated. Kahl noted that all discovery has been slower than originally anticipated by the Scoping Memo, that Southern California Edison has produced the data requested by CalCCA, that Pacific Gas and Electric Company posted a critical response to the PCIA forecast model on Friday, and that CalCCA is reviewing open items in coordination with the utilities. Kahl urged consideration of a six-week extension in the procedural schedule. Vaughan emphasized the critical importance of an extension under the circumstances to enable a fully informed discussion of issues.. Kahl noted that while CalCCA prefers to narrow issues through settlement, even with this extension there may not be sufficient time for meaningful settlement discussions. CalCCA representatives stated it does not oppose further extending the schedule beginning with the Proposed Decision mail date.

column6: JOINT; SUMMARY:  On January 29, 2018, Anna Foglesong, Director, Policy Analysis, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Cem Turhal, Principal, Regulatory Relations, for PG&E; Robert Anderson, Director, Resource Planning, and William Blattner, Manager, Regulatory Relations, for San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E); and Dawn Anaiscourt, Director, CPUC Regulatory Affairs, and Gary Stern, Director, Energy Policy, for Southern California Edison Company (SCE). PG&E’s, SDG&E’s and SCE’s representatives discussed the Joint Utilities’ broad support for the Proposed Decision Setting Requirements for Load Serving Entities (LSEs) Filing Integrated Resource Plans (IRPs) issued on December 28, 2017 in R.16-02-007 (PD), and their support for three key points in the PD. Among other things, PG&E, SDG&E and SCE stated that the Commission should exercise this authority to modify or reject CCA and/or ESP IRPs if they do not satisfy statutory and Commission requirements. PG&E, SDG&E and SCE also proposed three suggested revisions to the PD.

[Joint] SUMMARY:  On January 17, 2018, Billy Blattner of San Diego Gas & Electric Company, met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Nidhi Thakar, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and Erik Jacobson of Pacific Gas and Electric Company, and Diana Genasci of Southern California Edison Company.  The Joint Utilities’ representatives expressed support for Draft Resolution E-4907 (Draft Resolution), noting that the timing of the process of the Draft Resolution was appropriate and that the Commission has the regulatory authority to coordinate Resource Adequacy (RA) program timelines. The Joint Utilities’ representatives also observed the importance of the Commission timely approving the Draft Resolution. In addition, the Joint Utilities reiterated their willingness to negotiate mutually acceptable interim agreements with forming Community Choice Aggregators regarding short-term RA costs.

column5: Direct Access Customer Coalition,Alliance for Retail Energy Markets
column6: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On April 30, 2018, Mary Lynch of Constellation NewEnergy and Scott Olson of Direct Energy, representatives from the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Cynthia Clark of the University of California, George Waidelich of Albertsons and Chris Hendrix of Walmart representing Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC, and Dan Douglass, counsel to AReM and DACC, attended telephonically. Mr. Olson and Ms. Lynch explained that the allocation of Renewable Energy Credits and Resource Adequacy through the utilities’ GAM approach does not meet what other load-serving entities want and need. Mr. Fulmer described the elements of his testimony. Mr. Waidelich explained that DA customers desire energy cost stability and predictability and that the biggest impediment is the volatility and unpredictability of Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA). Mr. Waidelich recommended that the Commission should allow DA customers to pre-pay their PCIA obligation, based on a mutually acceptable forecast of that customer’s future PCIA obligation. Mr. Hendrix discussed the AReM/DACC proposal that the Commission should institute a cap on the PCIA. Mr. Fulmer clarified that there is already a “floor” in place and that adding a cap would create a “collar” where exposure of DA and bundled customers to volatility is more symmetric. Ms. Clark noted that DA customers in the current pre-2009 vintage tranche that have paid their stranded cost obligations should be permanently exempted from any PCIA or successor tariff.

EMAIL RULING CHANGING SCHEDULE FOR WORKSHOP.  The workshop that was originally to be scheduled no later than November 17, 2017 is deferred and shall now be conducted no later than January 19, 2018.

SUMMARY:  On November 2, 2017, Gary Stern, Director, Energy Policy, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with Cmmrs. Picker, Guzman Aceves, Peterman, Randolph, and Rechtschaffen during the Rulemaking 16-02-007 All Party Meeting on the Proposed Integrated Resource Planning (IRP) in San Francisco. Additionally, SCE believes that James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and Jason Houck, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, were present for all or portions of the All Party Meeting. Dr. Stern discussed the importance of cross-sector decarbonization opportunities in meeting the state’s greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction and air quality goals. Dr. Stern stated that transportation and building electrification are critical to achieving California’s GHG emissions reduction goals, and will also improve air quality, including in disadvantaged communities. Dr. Stern noted that the most significant contribution to air pollution in disadvantaged communities is transportation sources. Dr. Stern also discussed how the proposed IRP process may create disincentives for pursuing electrification unless electric sector and load-serving entity GHG emissions reduction targets are adjusted to account for increased load due to electrification.

SUMMARY:  On October 19, 2017, Geof Syphers, chief executive officer of Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCPA), accepted an invitation to serve on an hour-long panel discussion at the CAISO Symposium in which Commissioner Guzman-Aceves was acting as the moderator and numerous stakeholders were present.  Syphers commented on allegations that Community Choice Aggregators are not paying their fair share of exit fees, and noted that the investors’ owned utilities have not been willing to undergo an audit or provide information to substantiate that claim. In addition, Syphers stated that by electing to hold onto no-longer needed energy and related products in a falling market, Pacific Gas and Electric Company created costs that both bundled and unbundled ratepayers are responsible for.

ADVANCE THREE DAY NOTICE OF EX PARTE COMMUNICATION

SUMMARY:  On February 4, 2019, Billy Blattner, Manager of Regulatory Relations of San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), met with Amy Reardon, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Adenike Adeyeye, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and Kendall Helm, Vice President of Procurement of SDG&E, participated in the meeting by telephone. Referring to two options for Commission consideration of SDG&E’s proposed 59-month Resource Adequacy (RA) confirmation with the Otay Mesa Energy Center (OMEC), SDG&E clarified that the proposed RA confirmation does not impact the underlying contract and that the decision about whether or not to sell the plant to SDG&E, as provided in the original contract approved by the Commission, rests solely with the plant’s current owner. SDG&E addressed the Draft Resolutions’ descriptions of the net benefits analysis, clarifying that backstop procurement costs are likely to change over time and that altering assumptions to include insights from SDG&E’s recent Energy Resource Recovery Account filing or to allow for increases in net revenues in the future do not alter the finding that bundled customers are likely to capture net benefits under the term of the proposed confirmation. SDG&E emphasized that both bundled and departed/departing customers capture additional benefits through a shorter-term commitment to OMEC and the long-term optionality that results. SDG&E encouraged the Commission to vote out Option A. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

column5: Sierra Club and Union of Concerned Scientists
column6: SUMMARY:  On November 8, 2018, Matt Vespa, attorney for the Sierra Club and the Union of Concerned Scientists, and Alison Seel, attorney for the Sierra Club, met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker; and on November 9, 2018, with Yulia Schmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in separate meetings in San Francisco.  The representatives of the Sierra Club and Union of Concerned Scientists requested that the Commission put an end to Southern California Gas Company’s (SoCalGas) use ratepayer funds to oppose needed electrification efforts across the state. Mr. Vespa referred to multiple examples of SoCalGas customer communications and policy advocacy activities that provided false and misleading information on building and transportation electrification to policy makers and the public. Mr. Vespa also discussed Sierra Club’s serious concerns with SoCalGas’ request to procure additional natural gas vehicles and to triple its current investment in natural gas refueling stations. Ms. Seel cautioned the Commission about permitting further investment in fossil fuel infrastructure. Ms. Seel referred to the testimony of The Utility Reform Network in this proceeding. Ms. Seel explained why the California Energy Commission should administer the entirety of the state’s natural gas research and development budget. Mr. Vespa asked the Commission to deny the $21 million request for application costs for the rejected North-South Pipeline. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

column5: Sierra Club and Union of Concerned Scientists
column6: SUMMARY:  On December 5, 2018, attorneys Matt Vespa, representing Sierra Club and the Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS), and Alison Seel, representing Sierra Club, met with Cmmr. Guzman Aceves and Adenike Adeyeye, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves; and on December 6, 2018, met with Rachel Peterson, Anand Durvasula, and Suzanne Casazza, advisors to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco. Sierra Club and UCS’s representatives focused on Sierra Club and UCS’s request that the Commission put an end to Southern California Gas Company’s (SoCalGas) use ratepayer funds to oppose needed electrification efforts across the state. Ms. Seel raised examples of SoCalGas customer communications and policy advocacy activities that provided false and misleading information on building and transportation electrification to policy makers and the public. Mr. Vespa emphasized that while such activities are to be expected from a fossil fuel company with a shareholder interest in maintaining demand for natural gas, they are a highly inappropriate use of ratepayer funds. Mr. Vespa also discussed Sierra Club’s serious concerns with SoCalGas’ request to procure additional natural gas vehicles and to triple its current investment in natural gas refueling stations. Ms. Seel additionally cautioned the Commission about permitting further investment in fossil fuel infrastructure like refueling stations at a time when the state is moving away from fossil fuels and these investments will soon be stranded. Mr. Vespa explained why the California Energy Commission should administer the entirety of the state’s natural gas research and development budget. Finally, Mr. Vespa asked the Commission to deny the $21 million request for application costs for the rejected North-South Pipeline.

SUMMARY:  On October 30, 2018, Kendall Helm, Vice President – Procurement, and Billy Blattner, Manager - Regulatory Relations, of San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and on November 1, 2018 – with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in two separate meetings. All three meetings were held in San Francisco. In the meeting on October 30, 2018 also present was Ryan Miller, Manager - Energy Supply and Dispatch, and in the meetings on November 1, 2018, Dan Skopec, Vice President – Regulatory Affairs, of SDG&E. SDG&E representatives provided an overview of a proposed 59-month Resource Adequacy (RA) contract for the capacity of the Otay Mesa Energy Center (OMEC) filed with the Commission by Tier 2 advice letter, as well as the utility’s portfolio planning and cost allocation responsibilities. SDG&E explained that if the proposed contract is approved (final and non-appealable) on or before March 15, 2019, the existing option for OMEC LLC to sell (put) the plant to SDG&E under the current Commission-approved contract would be relinquished and SDG&E would remove the associated revenue requirement from its General Rate Case. SDG&E concluded that the RA contract is in its bundled customers’ interest, consistent with Senate Bill 100, and will not jeopardize reliability. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 15, 2018, Powers, technical consultant to Protect Our Communities Foundation (POC), met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Jamie Pang, staff counsel to POC, participated in the meeting by telephone conference. POC representatives provided a brief background and history of the Otay Mesa Energy Center, and reviewed the purchase in the context of the power charge indifference cost proceeding. POC indicated that SDG&E should not be authorized to purchase more utility-owned gas-fired generation, and that at a minimum the proposed purchase should be subject to a separate application. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On August 9, 2018, Bill Powers, technical consultant, and Jamie Pang, staff counsel, to Protect Our Communities Foundation (POC) POC met in San Francisco with Yulia Schmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen and Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings; and on August 10, 2018, with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves. Also present at the meeting with Yulia Schmidt was Laura Martin of the Energy Division; and Ty Tosdal, outside counsel to POC participated in the meetings with Yulia Schmidt and Ehren Seybert by telephone conference. POC representatives provided the background and history of the Otay Mesa Energy Center (OMEC), and reviewed the disproportionately high level of SDG&E utility-owned gas-fired generation relative to much larger PG&E and SCE. At the meeting with David Gamson, POC representatives briefly discussed the PCIA cost associated with OMEC, and the future PCIA implications of SDG&E purchasing OMEC. In each of these meetings POC indicated that SDG&E should not be authorized to purchase more utility-owned gas-fired generation, and that at a minimum the proposed purchase should be subject to a separate application. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.
