SUMMARY:  On July 31, 2018, Norman A. Pedersen, attorney for the Southern California Publicly Owned Utilities (SCPOU) had a communication with Cmmr. Randolph at the Technical Workshop on the Aliso Canyon Scenarios Framework at the Simi Valley City Council Chambers, Simi Valley. The communication was during a period for comments on the Aliso Canyon hydraulic and economic modeling framework. Also present were Jean Spencer, Khaled Abdelaziz, Donald Brooks, and Mounir Fellahi of the Energy Division; Sabina Clorfeine and Jason Egan, attorneys, and other personnel, of the Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas). Between 50 and 100 other persons were present during the communication, and an unknown number of persons, possibly including decisionmakers, viewed the webcast of the Workshop. In the course of his oral comments, Mr. Pedersen stated that an issue pending in this proceeding is whether core gas suppliers should balance daily deliveries of scheduled quantities to the SoCalGas system with actual daily consumption by the core customers served by the core gas suppliers. Mr. Pedersen explained that if core gas suppliers were permitted to continue to balance daily scheduled quantities to a daily forecast rather than actual core usage, the core suppliers could be deemed to be in balance within Operational Flow Order (“OFO”) tolerances even though their imbalances between scheduled quantities and actual consumption exceeded OFO tolerances. Mr. Pedersen observed that a question raised in the Update to the Scenarios Framework dated June 15, 2018 is the percentage utilization of “maximum available scheduling capacity.”  Mr. Pedersen also noted that issues related to trading of scheduled daily quantities are pending in the consolidated A.17-10-007 and A.17-10-008.

SUMMARY:  On July 25, 2018, Jeff Rosenbaum, Portfolio Manager of Elliott Management Corporation (Elliott), met with Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and Geoffrey Dryvynsyde, Assistant General Counsel, and also met with Jennifer Kalafut and John Reynolds, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present were Joe Jackson, Associate Portfolio Manager, Brian Gunderson, Head of Public Affairs, Scott Grinsell, Assistant General Counsel, and Steven F. Greenwald of Davis Wright Tremaine LLP, outside counsel, for Elliott. The Elliott representatives discussed their and Bluescape Energy Resources Company’s initiatives with respect to Sempra Energy. Specifically, the Elliott representatives described their belief that Sempra Energy should immediately refresh its Board at the holding-company level by adding new directors that are highly qualified and would inject independent, objective, fresh thinking to the Company.

SUMMARY:  On July 19, 2018, Kimberly Cluff, General Counsel of Morongo Band of Mission Indians (Morongo) met with Jennifer Kalafut, John Reynolds, and Geoffrey Dryvynsyde, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present was Vidhya Prabhakaran, outside counsel to Morongo. The Morongo representatives provided some background and history about the Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas) transmission gas pipeline rights of way (ROW) that traverse the Morongo Reservation. The Morongo representatives provided some information about the potential future economic development for Morongo associated with the ROWs. The Morongo representatives also discussed its ongoing and current ROW negotiations with SoCalGas and raised some questions about the possible effects of the outcome of those negotiations on system-wide reliability in Southern California.

column6: SDG&E and SoCalGas noticed an oral and written ex parte communication with Rachel Peterson, Chief of Staff and Joanna Gubman, Energy Advisor from the Office of Commissioner Randolph; Maria Sotero, Advisor to Commissioner Guzman-Aceves; and Energy Division staff on March 12, 2018.
ASSIGNED COMMISSIONER’S RULING ON LOST AND UNACCOUNTED FOR GAS ISSUE

SUMMARY:  On February 14, 2018, Gillian Wright, Vice President of Customer Services for Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas), met with Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco.  Also present were Sarah Sharpe, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, Dorris Chow, Dorothy Duda, Franz Cheng, Eugene Cadenasso, Phil Enis, Risa Hernandez and Juanita Lane, of the Commission Energy Division and Consumer Affairs, and Kari Kloberdanz-Yu, Regulatory Relations Manager, SoCalGas. .On February 20, 2018, Ms. Kloberdanz-Yu provided a follow up email to Ms. Sotero and Ms. Sharpe with a correction to two statements made in the February 14 meeting. During the meeting, Ms. Wright discussed the voluntary changes that SoCalGas implemented to their gas reconnection process. Ms. Wright provided details regarding the manual scheduling process of all requests for reconnection of service following disconnection for nonpayment, and the commitment to offer a reconnection appointment no later than the next business day, with Saturday acting as a business day, or the second business day for requests made after 5pm on Saturday or on a Sunday. Ms. Wright discussed how this timing is comparable to other gas-only utility practices in the United States. Ms. Wright further discussed the scheduling of upcoming focus groups with customers. Ms. Wright and Ms. Kloberdanz-Yu discussed the more appropriate forum for addressing reconnection protocols. Ms. Wright and Ms. Kloberdanz-Yu further indicated that a motion seeking that relief was forthcoming in the active GRC proceeding. A copy of the February 20, 2018 email is attached to the notice.

column5: San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E),Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas)
column6: [JOINT] THREE-DAY ADVANCE NOTICE OF EX PARTE COMMUNICATION

Summary:  On February 12, 2018, Mila Buckner, attorney for Coalition of California Utility Employees (CUE), met with Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present were Sarah Sharpe, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves; Edward Randolph, Director of the Energy Division, and Dorothy Duda, Franz Cheng, Dorris Chow and Eugene Cadenasso, Staff of the Energy Division; Phillip Enis and Risa Hernandez, Staff of the Consumer Protection and Enforcement Division; and Jerry Acosta, Javier Salas, and Belinda Moreno, representatives of UWUA. UWUA representatives explained the steps Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas) takes when a customer fails to pay their bill and their gas service is shut off as well as what happens when a customer resolves an outstanding bill and requests that gas service be restored. Moreno explained that many customers do not realize they need to call SoCalGas and request that service be restored after they pay their bill. Moreno stated that customers who call in may experience long wait times or may struggle to reach a Spanish/Chinese speaking representative, and that for the past 5-10 years SoCalGas has failed to hire enough Customer Service Representatives to take these calls. Moreno stated that once a work order is placed, customers wait, on average, two weeks for their service to be restored. Salas and Acosta explained that SoCalGas has approximately 938 ETR and 130 ETRA employees who are qualified to restore gas service in a customer’s home. Salas and Acosta explained that while the utility has grown in size, SoCalGas has failed to hire an adequate number of employees to keep up with customer service demands.

column5: Coalition Cities: City of San Luis Obispo, City of Pismo Beach, City of Paso Robles, City of Arroyo
column6: SUMMARY:  On January 4, 2017, representatives of the City of San Luis Obispo, City of Pismo Beach, City of Paso Robles, City of Arroyo Grande, City of Morro Bay, and City of Atascadero (collectively, the “Coalition Cities”) met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. On behalf of the Coalition Cities, present at the meeting were Heidi Harmon (Mayor, City of San Luis Obispo), Erik Howell (City Councilmember, City of Pismo Beach), Christine Dietrick (City Attorney, City of San Luis Obispo), and Britt Strottman (outside counsel). Tom Frutchey (City Manager, City of Paso Robles) participated in the meeting by telephone. The representatives for the Coalition Cities discussed the Community Impacts Mitigation Program (CIMP). Specifically, the Coalition Cities discussed why the Commission has legal authority to approve ratepayer funding for the CIMP, that the CIMP is not a substitute for lost tax revenue, how the parties calculated the $10 million for the Economic Development Fund, the concerns about the safety and economic impact of the closure of Diablo Canyon, and the reasons why the CIMP benefits ratepayers.

column5: San Luis Coastal Unified School District
column6: [LATE FILED] SUMMARY:  On November 20, 2017, Kimberly McGrath, Assistant Superintendent for Education, San Luis Coastal Unified School District (SLCUSD), met with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present was Gregory Klatt, outside counsel to SLCUSD. Ms. McGrath and Mr. Klatt gave an overview of SLCUSD and its unique relationship with PG&E and the Diablo Canyon Power Plant. Ms. McGrath and Mr. Klatt explained the basis for SLCUSD’s position that it would be fair, and the Commission has the legal authority, to authorize ratepayer funding of the CIMP. Ms. McGrath and Mr. Klatt also described SLCUSD’s efforts to ensure the Community Impacts Mitigation Program (CIMP) was structured in a manner that would produce the intended results and the consequences of the CIMP not being adopted.

SUMMARY:  On September 21, 2017, Steven Kelly, Policy Director for the Independent Energy Producers Association (IEP), met with Sandy Goldberg, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco. Also present was Brian Cragg, outside counsel to IEP. Kelly pointed out that the Diablo Canyon retirement proceeding and the Renewables Portfolio Standard (RPS) procurement plan proceeding provided the Commission with an opportunity to authorize procurement of renewable energy resources in time for the projects to qualify for the federal Investment Tax Credit (ITC) and Production Tax Credit (PTC) by 2019. Kelly emphasized that unless the Commission orders a solicitation for renewable resources in late 2017 or early 2018, the significant value of the tax incentives will be lost. Kelly noted that the timing of additional procurement of renewable energy is critical.  In the Diablo Canyon proceeding, IEP urged the Commission to direct Pacific Gas and Electric Company to conduct an all-source solicitation for up to 4,000 GWh by no later than July 2018. In the RPS procurement plan proceeding, IEP has urged the Commission to exercise the authority provided in Public Utilities Code section 399.15(bX3) and require jurisdictional load-serving entities to procure higher levels of renewable resources than the minimums specified in section 399. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On September 18, 2017, Mark Pocta, Program Manager for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in in San Francisco. Also present were Daniel Buch, Program and Project Supervisor, and Michael Campbell, Program Manager, for the ORA. Pocta described the ratemaking portions of the proceeding including ORA’s recommendation that shareholders fund the “Community Impacts Mitigation Program.” ORA expressed its support of the settlement between Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), the Alliance for Nuclear Responsibility, The Utility Reform Network, ORA and others that includes, for ratepayer funding, $18.6 million in license renewal costs, and excludes Allowance for Funds Under Construction for canceled capital projects. ORA discussed its opposition to PG&E’s request for ratepayer funding of the $1.3 billion “Tranche 1” replacement energy proposal as unjustified. Finally, ORA noted that it supports authorizing $160.5 million for employee retention payments that PG&E can allocate as it sees fit, but ORA does not support the excessively expensive plan PG&E wants customers to fund.

[By Decisionmaker]  SUMMARY:  On August 2, 2018, David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, met in San Francisco with Sydney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, and Daniel Pease, Principal Rate Analyst, Rates and Regulatory Analytics, for Pacific Gas & Electric Company.

[By Decisionmaker]  SUMMARY:  On July 12, 2018, David Gamson, Advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, met in San Francisco Melissa W. Kasnitz, Legal Director, and Chloe Stapleton-Gray, summer intern, for Center for Accessible Technology.
Decision D1808013 - Decision on Pacific Gas and Electric Company's Proposed Rate Design and Related Issues. Application 16-06-013.

column5: County of San Joaquin,County of Santa Clara
column6: [Joint] SUMMARY:  On August 2, 2018, Ann Trowbridge, counsel to the County of Santa Clara (CSC), met with Yuliya Schmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in four separate meetings in San Francisco; and had a telephone communication with Jason Houck, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. Shirley R. Edwards, Deputy County Counsel, Lin Ortega, Utilities Engineer/Program Manager, and Brad Vance, Utility Program Analyst, Facilities and Fleet Department, for CSC, and Jim Stone, Deputy Director of Operations, County of San Joaquin (CSJ), participated in each communication; and Steven Moss, consultant to CSC, participated in the meetings with Jason Houck, David Peck, and David Gamson. Ms. Trowbridge explained that CSC owns and operates several Renewable Energy Self-Generation Bill Credit Transfer (RES-BCT); CSJ is developing a RESBCT project, but it is on hold given the rate uncertainty posed by this proceeding. Ms. Trowbridge further explained that the Counties support the Proposed Decision’s (PD) recognition of the “essential differences” between the Net Energy Metering (“NEM”) program and the RESBCT program and its directive that Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) modify the TOU Settlement Agreement rate design for legacy RES-BCT customers. Ms. Trowbridge stated that the Counties believe further clarification is required regarding the methodology to be used to ensure an equitable result for legacy RES-BCT customers. Mr. Ortega explained the difference in NEM and RES-BCT net bill impacts. Mr. Ortega and Mr. Vance summarized the Counties’ proposal to apply a 6.2% net bill impact in 2023 for legacy RES-BCT customers. Mr. Ortega and Mr. Vance explained that PG&E’s analysis of what it believes to be an “equal treatment” methodology under the PD would result in a 26.5% net bill impact for legacy RES-BCT customers, and would render the Counties’ investments in their RES-BCT projects uneconomic during each year of the term of the TOU Settlement Agreement. Mr. Ortega and Mr. Vance further explained that PG&E’s proposal would result in solar credits valued below CSC’s investment repayment obligations. Mr. Stone and Ms. Edwards explained the County services benefiting from the RES-BCT program. Ms. Edwards and Ms. Trowbridge expressed the Counties’ support for the PD’s suggested treatment of legacy RES-BCT customers as complying with applicable law. In the meetings with Ms. Schmidt and Mr. Seybert, Ms. Trowbridge, Mr. Ortega and Mr. Vance clarified that if the pending Advice Letter cited in PG&E’s reply comments is approved, it would not make a meaningful difference in the net bill impact to legacy RES-BCT customers under PG&E’s proposal. In the meetings with Mr. Peck and Mr. Gamson, Mr. Moss clarified PG&E did not propose a process through which its proposed methodology would be evaluated, instead implying that its proposal would automatically be adopted as a tariff or its equivalent. In the meetings with Mr. Seybert, Mr. Peck, and Mr. Gamson, Ms. Trowbridge noted that the Counties believe their proposed methodology is also consistent with the guidance provided to affected parties in Southern California Edison Company’s Rate Design Window proceeding. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On July 30, 2018, Sheila Dey, Executive Director, and Edward Poole, Counsel, for the Western Manufactured Housing Community Association (WMA), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Sheila Dey urged the Commission to review the proposed decision and consider recalculating the discount based on average residential class costs as being consistent with Decision 17-09-035 and with Section 739.5. Mr. Poole discussed the argument in WMA’s opening brief that discussed recalculating the discount without a DMA adjustment. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On July 30, 2018, Rick Umoff, Regulatory Counsel and California Director, State Affairs the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA), and Damon Franz, of Tesla, a SEIA member company, met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. The SEIA representatives discussed the Proposed Decision (PD) which was issued in on July 5, 2018. In particular, the SEIA representatives discussed the PD’s adoption, with modifications, SEIA’s Option S proposal for a storage-friendly rate for Pacific Gas and Electric Company’s Medium and large Light and Power customers. The SEIA representatives noted that a key feature of Option S is the innovation of a daily demand charge that applies during the 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. peak period to replace 80% of the non-coincident demand charges that apply 24 hours a day. The SEIA representatives stated that SEIA could accept the changes to its proposed Option S made in the PD, including basing the Option S daily demand charge based on 80% of the distribution non-coincident demand charges and capping the availability of Option S at 324 MW. The SEIA representatives talked about the relief afforded RES-BCT customers under the PD and supported the proposal made by the Counties of Santa Clara and San Joaquin in their comments on the Proposed Decision as to how to implement that relief.

[By Decisionmaker]  SUMMARY:  On July 23, 2018, Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, had a telephone conversation with Matthew Freedman, staff attorney, The Utility Reform Network.

SUMMARY:  On July 31, 2018, Matthew Freedman, staff attorney of The Utility Reform Network (TURN), spoke on the telephone with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman. TURN offered support for the Master Meter Discount methodology in the Proposed Decision of ALJ Doherty (PD) and urged the Commission not to make the changes proposed by the Western Manufactured Housing Association (WMA), including the elimination of the Diversity Benefit Adjustment and the use of residential class average costs to calculate the base discount. TURN also urged changes to the PD to remove the adoption of the marginal cost values proposed by Pacific Gas and Electric Company for purposes other than those expressly identified in the revenue allocation settlement. TURN expressed support for efforts to assist customers in hot, inland areas through the Family Energy Assistance rate program, adjustments to baseline quantities and other rate discounts. Mr. Freedman also pointed out that the residential rate settlement, which would be approved under the PD, reduces the baseline summer season to exclude the month of May. Mr. Freedman explained that this change benefits customers in hot climate zones by increasing the summer baseline allowance for the remaining months. Mr. Freedman expressed TURN’s interest in working to develop additional programs and strategies, in other proceedings, to achieve affordable rates for residential customers located in hot climates.
Reply comments on the Proposed Decision of ALJ Doherty.

SUMMARY:  On July 24, 2018, Rick Umoff, Regulatory Counsel and California Director, State Affairs the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, with Jason Houck, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in three separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present were Thomas Beach, consultant for SEIA, Blair Swezey of SunPower, and Rachel Bird of Borrego Solar, both SEIA member companies. The SEIA representatives discussed the Proposed Decision (PD) which was issued in on July 5, 2018. In particular, the SEIA representatives discussed the PD’s adoption, with modifications, SEIA’s Option S proposal for a storage-friendly rate for Pacific Gas and Electric Company’s Medium and large Light and Power customers. The SEIA representatives noted that a key feature of Option S is the innovation of a daily demand charge that applies during the 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. peak period to replace 80% of the non-coincident demand charges that apply 24 hours a day. The SEIA representatives stated that SEIA could accept the changes to its proposed Option S made in the PD, including basing the Option S daily demand charge based on 80% of the distribution non-coincident demand charges and capping the availability of Option S at 324 MW.

SUMMARY:  On July 13, 2018, Matthew Freedman, staff attorney for The Utility Reform Network (TURN), spoke on the telephone with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves. TURN offered support for the portions of the Proposed Decision (PD) of ALJ Doherty that direct Pacific Gas and Electric Company to increase the rate of participation in the Family Energy Assistance rate program so that at least 50% of eligible customers are enrolled prior to its next Phase 2 General Rate Case. Mr. Freedman noted the need for additional outreach to achieve this goal but urged the Commission not to approve any additional funding for this purpose as part of the current proceeding. Mr. Freedman pointed out that the residential rate settlement, which would be approved under the PD, reduces the baseline summer season to exclude the month of May. Mr. Freedman noted that this change benefits customers in hot climate zones by increasing the summer baseline allowance for the remaining months. TURN offered support for additional increases to residential baselines for hot climate zones that could be considered in future proceedings. Mr. Freedman expressed TURN’s interest in working to develop additional programs and strategies, in other proceedings, to achieve affordable rates for residential customers located in hot climates.

SUMMARY:  On July 12, 2018, Melissa W. Kasnitz, Legal Director of, and Chloe Stapleton-Gray, a summer intern with, Center for Accessible Technology (CforAT), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Ms. Kasnitz discussed the Proposed Decision of ALJ Doherty (the PD) which was issued on July 5, 2018. Ms. Kasnitz addressed the importance of the PD’s provisions requiring increased efforts to raise enrollment levels for FERA, with a long-term goal of bringing FERA enrollment in line with enrollment levels in CARE, and the importance of the study of what constitutes an essential amount of electricity for PG&E’s residential customers. Ms. Kasnitz also discussed the provisions of the residential settlement addressed in the PD, which modify PG&E’s Medical Baseline program, and generally discussed the importance of the Medical Baseline program.

Notice of Ex Parte Communication of Advisor.  Sean Simon, Chief of Staff to Commissioner Clifford Rechtschaffen, noticed ex parte communication with the Office of Ratepayer Advocates and Solar Energy Industries Association, on September 7, 2017, at 2:30 p.m.

SUMMARY:  On September 7, 2017, Michael Campbell, Program Manager for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in two separate meetings in San Francisco offices.  At the meeting with Candace Morey also present was Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves.  Charlyn Hook, Attorney, and Christopher Danforth, Analyst, for ORA, and Brandon Smithwood of the Solar Energy Industries Association (the Joint Parties) participated in both meetings.  The Joint Parties discussed their support for the Proposed Decision (PD) Identifying Fixed Cost Categories to be Included in a Fixed Charge.  The Joint Parties stated that the PD properly determined the categories of fixed costs that could be recovered in a fixed charge, consistent with the guidance developed in Decision (D.) 15-07-001 to limit fixed charges to customer-related costs. The Joint Parties noted that, while the PD did not adopt a methodology for determining fixed costs, it did achieve a careful balancing of included and excluded costs that the Joint Parties support.  The Joint Parties explained their position in the proceeding that the entire cost of the transformer, service and meter should be excluded from the fixed charge.  The Joint Parties provided some background and context on residential fixed charges, pointing out that Public Utilities Code § 739.9 authorizes, but does not require, the Commission to adopt a fixed charge for residential customers.  The Joint Parties described some history of fixed charges on utility bills, which have not been popular with customers.  Copies of the comments filed with the Commission, D.15-07-001 and Public Utilities Code § 739.9 were used during the meeting with advisors  to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves.
NOTICE OF PREHEARING CONFERENCE.

column5: Pacific Gas and Electric Company,Southern California Edison,San Diego Gas & Electric Company
column6: SUMMARY:  JOINT.  On August 29 and 30, 2017, Sidney Dietz, Director of Regulatory Relations for Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), had three separate ex parte meetings in San Francisco.  On August 29, 2017, Dietz met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in two separate meetings; and on August 30, 2017, with Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen.  At the meeting with Ehren Seybert also present were John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves.  Also present at all three meetings were Margot Everett, Senior Director of Rates and Regulatory Analytics, for PG&E; Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs for San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E); and Laura Genao, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Russ Garwicki, Director of Pricing Design and Research, for Southern California Edison Company (SCE).  Dietz stated that the proceeding was designed to decide what could be included in a fixed charge, but instead, the Proposed Decision (PD) prematurely limits consideration the costs of equipment that is fixed in nature.  Genao stated that the PD represents a complete departure from the Commission precedent by stating that service drops and final-line transformers are not fixed costs.  Genao further stated that the PD should identify what costs could be included in a fixed charge, not limit the CPUC’s ability to consider the costs for some types of equipment.  Everett stated that the PD moves the California away from a cost-causation model, which is reflected in precedent and in the goals of AB327. Garwicki described past proceedings where the CPUC, rather than decide how much of each piece of equipment contributed to fixed and variable costs, drew a conceptual line at the final transformer for customer costs and grid costs to be treated separately.  Prusnek stated that the PD creates an inconsistency among customer classes.  Everett stated that fixed charges, because of the cost categories involved, would apply to Community Choice Aggregation customers as well.

REPLY COMMENTS ON ASSIGNED COMMISSIONER’S RULING SEEKING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION AND COMMENT AS IT RELATES TO ELECTRIC BASELINES

SUMMARY:  On February 5, 2018, Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present were Neha Bazaj of the CPUC Energy Division; and Dennis Keane, Chief Regulatory Analyst, Rates and Regulatory Analytics, Deb Ghosh, Senior Manager, Electric Rates, and Phillip Quadrini, Expert Rate Analyst, Electric Rates, for PG&E. Citing to Figure 1 in PG&E’s January 31, 2018 Opening Comments Responding to Appendix B Questions, Mr. Keane stated that the effect of changing baselines has a nonlinear effect on bills – it increases bills for the lowest-usage and the highest-usage customers, but can lower or increase bills for other customers depending upon a variety of factors. Mr. Keane further stated that reducing rate differentials between tiers has a greater effect than baseline changes on high customer bills, as would the implementation of a fixed charge that lowered volumetric rates. Mr. Keane also described why implementing a fixed charge, even if the resulting revenue it collects only offsets the Tier 1 rate (as is the case when the rate ratios are defined relative to the composite Tier 1 rate rather than to the actual Tier 1 rate), still provides somewhat lower bills for upper-tier consuming customers. Mr. Keane stated that the current method for setting baseline quantities results in average rates that are approximately equal across all baseline territories. Mr. Keane and Mr. Quadrini stated that a more effective way to provide relief to Central Valley customers with high bills would be to implement a fixed charge, due to their significantly higher usage compared to other areas.

Notice of Ex Parte Communication of Advisors.  David Gamson, Advisor to Commissioner Martha Guzman Aceves, noticed oral ex parte communication of Ehren Seybert and John Reynolds, Advisors to Commissioner Carla Peterman, and David Gamson, Advisor to Commissioner Martha Guzman Aceves, with Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Diego Gas & Electric Company, and Southern California Edison Company, on August 29, 2017 at approximately 1:00 p.m.

SUMMARY:  On September 20, 2017, Michael Campbell, Program Manager for offices the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present were Christopher Danforth, Analyst, and Charlyn Hook, Attorney, for ORA, and Brandon Smithwood for the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA) (the Joint Parties).  The Joint Parties discussed their support for the Proposed Decision (PD) of Identifying Fixed Cost Categories to be Included in a Fixed Charge. The Joint Parties stated that the PD properly determined the categories of fixed costs that could be recovered in a fixed charge, consistent with the guidance developed in Decision 15-07-001 to limit fixed charges to customer-related costs.  The Joint Parties explained that the Joint Utilities’ proposal for including a host of costs in a fixed charge would result in increased costs for the smaller Tier 1 residential customers, adding to cumulative bill increases from tier flattening.  The Joint Parties explained how increasing revenue requirement recovery through a fixed charge and decreasing volumetric charges is contrary to state policy goals and dampens the price signal to conserve energy.  The Joint Parties also discussed the questions that were issued for the All-Party meeting on September 21, 2017. The Joint Parties discussed different ways that they could be answered, but stated that were unable to speculate on how different approaches asked about in the questions would affect the fixed charge.

SUMMARY:  On September 8, 2017, Linda Serizawa, Deputy Director of the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco.  Also present were Candace Morey and Maria Sotero, advisors to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and Darwin E. Farrar, Chief Counsel, Michael Campbell and Lee-Whei Tan, Program Managers, and Dexter Khoury, Regulatory Analyst, for ORA.  ORA representatives discussed the effects of the recent heat wave and changing weather patterns in general, on baseline rates in the Central Valley and other high temperature zones in California, in the context of the Phase II rate design issues in this proceeding.

column5: San Diego Gas & Electric Company,Pacific Gas and Electric Company,Southern California Edison Company
column6: Opening comments on Proposed Decision.
PROOF OF RULE 13.1(c) COMPLIANCE

SUMMARY:  On July 31, 2017, Sidney Dietz, Director of Regulatory Relations for Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present was Dennis Keane, Chief Rate Analyst, Rates and Regulatory Analytics, for PG&E.  Dietz stated that the petition to modify to allow an additional two-year grace period for PG&E’s non-residential customers to qualify for grandfathering on Time-of-Use (TOU) rates with obsolete TOU periods is not required for the health of the solar industry.  Keane described the concept and rationale for limited grandfathering of customers with solar, and noted that Decision 17-01-006 was a reasonable compromise that limited the amount of customer load allowed to be grandfathered on legacy TOU rates with outdated TOU period hours.  Keane also noted that PG&E has submitted comments stating it would not object to one additional proposed change to the grandfathering rules which would establish a somewhat-later installation deadline for schools.  Dietz stated that, while PG&E is supportive of this change to the decision, the additional grandfathering requested in the solar groups’ petition for modification is not warranted.  Keane stated that (a) PG&E has proposed, in its 2017 GRC Phase II case a 5 pm to 10 pm peak period for its non-residential TOU rate schedules, which are not expected to be implemented until 2019; (b) PG&E has proposed a 4 pm to 9 pm peak period for the upcoming residential default TOU pilot, which will commence in early 2018; and (c) PG&E will likely propose, in its upcoming 2018 Rate Design Window proceeding (that will be filed in December 2017), identical 4 pm to 9 pm peak period hours for the full roll-out of residential default TOU rates scheduled to begin in 2019.  Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

[By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On January 18, 2019, Amy Reardon, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, met in San Francisco with Jeanne Solé, Deputy Director of Power Resources of San Jose Clean Energy, Alicia Priego, consultant and lobbyist for the City of San Jose, and Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel of East Bay Community Energy.

column5: East Bay Community Energy,Peninsula Clean Energy
column6: SUMMARY:  On January 24, 2019, Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), Jeremy Waen, Manager of Regulatory Affairs of Peninsula Clean Energy (PCE), and Tim Lindl, Partner, Keyes & Fox LLP, met with Amy Reardon, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, and Mitchell Shapson, Attorney with the Legal Division, in San Francisco. EBCE and PCE (collectively, CCAs) representatives discussed the disposition of issues within the Assigned Commissioner’s Alternate Proposed Decision. The CCAs representatives noted the importance of implementing the brown power true-up for the “target year” 2018 in 2019 rates. More specifically, the CCAs discussed how this would correct a $267 million forecasting error, $109 million of which is from unbundled customers without a mechanism to make them whole. The CCAs also pointed out how their request to true up brown power costs follows directly from D.18-10-019.

[By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On January 3, 2019, Amy Reardon and Sarah Sharpe, advisors to Cmmr. column5: East Bay Community Energy,Peninsula Clean Energy
column6: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On December 6, 2018, Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), Jeremy Waen, Manager of Regulatory Affairs of Peninsula Clean Energy (PCE), and Tim Lindl, Partner at Keyes & Fox LLP, (together the “CCAs”), met with Forest Kaser and James Ralph, advisors to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  The CCAs noted how this Energy Resource Recovery Account (ERRA) forecast application was unusual compared to other years’ ERRA forecast proceedings due to the substantial sales of energy and capacity that would occur in 2019 and due to the implementation of the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) decision, D.18-10-019. The CCAs discussed why the Commission should value multi-year sales of RPSeligible energy, RA capacity and brown power at the relevant benchmark for the purpose of forecasting the PCIA. The CCAs noted how PG&E’s approach to forecasting these non-resource specific sales contracts at the projected sales price does not comply with statute, the PCIA decision, other Commission precedent, the scope of the ERRA proceeding, or a reasonableness standard. The CCAs explained how PG&E’s modifications to the PCIA’s allocation factors are responsible for 56.5% of the increase in the PCIA between its September 7, 2018 Rebuttal Testimony and the November Update. The CCAs further explained how those modifications were not approved by D.18-10-019 and, therefore, should not be implemented in this ERRA. The CCAs urged the Commission to implement the brown power true-up for 2018 rates as soon as possible. The CCAs noted the on-going transparency issues in the ERRA where few of the issues in PG&E’s prepared, rebuttal and updated testimony, including the substantial shifts in policy represented therein, are clearly explained.
[By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On October 26, 2018, Maria Sotero and David Gamson, advisors to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, met in San Francisco with representative(s) of East Bay Community Energy.

column6: Comments on Update to Pacific Gas and Electric Company’s prepared testimony.
Response to the 2019 ERRA Forecast Application November Update of Pacific Gas and Electric Company.
Motion to seal the evidentiary record under Rule 11.5.
EMAIL RULING CALIFORNIA LARGE ENERGY CONSUMERS ASSOCIATION PARTY STATUS

SUMMARY:  On October 26, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel of East Bay Community Energy, met with Maria Sotero and David Gamson, advisors to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Ms. Brandt discussed the need for the brown-power true up as required by D.18-10-019 to be implemented immediately in the PCIA rate update. Ms. Brandt expressed concern that the Energy Division RA Report that will be used to determine the capacity value in the PCIA benchmark does not reflect enough of the actual market transactions, nor are updates to the report frequent enough. Ms. Brandt suggested that requirements for what the report should include and when it is released may need to be codified in a future ERRA decision since it is used to set rates in the ERRA proceeding. Ms. Brandt further raised concerns about the timing of implementation of the PCIA decision in the ERRA, and about the interpretation of details that will need to be worked out for effective implementation.

SUMMARY:  On February 5, 2019, Erik Jacobson, Director, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Amy Reardon and Johnathan Koltz, advisors to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present were Kurt Hansen, Director, Portfolio and Resource Forecasting, and Sharon Pierson, Senior Manager, Electric Rates, of PG&E. PG&E proposed some modifications to the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD). PG&E representatives explained that it is premature to implement a Brown Power true-up through this 2019 ERRA forecast decision. PG&E also recommends that Ordering Paragraph 2 of the APD be revised so that actual tariff sheets are not required for the Advice Letter filing. Finally, PG&E representatives explained that while PG&E would have preferred resolving the problem of calculating proper billing determinates in this proceeding, PG&E was comfortable deferring the issue to Phase 2 of the PCIA rulemaking.

column5: East Bay Community Energy,San Jose Clean Energy
column6: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On January 18, 2019, Lori Mitchell, Director of Community Energy, and Jeanne Solé, Deputy Director of Power Resources, of San José Clean Energy (SJCE), Alicia Priego, consultant and lobbyist for the City of San Jose, and Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE) (together the “CCAs”), met with Amy Reardon, advisor to Commissioner Martha Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Ms. Mitchell and Ms. Priego attended the meeting via telephone. The CCAs representatives discussed the revised Proposed Decision’s (PD). SJCE described the high housing costs in San Jose and the large proportion of disadvantaged residents in the city. SJCE explained that it will start serving residential and commercial customers in February 2019. SJCE stressed the importance of a fair and timely outcome in the Energy Resource Recovery Account (ERRA). The CCAs urged the Commission to implement the brown power true-up for the “target year” 2018 in 2019 rates. The CCAs pointed out how their request to true up brown power costs first follows directly from D.18-10-019. The CCAs referred to a January 4, 2019, ex parte notice by Peninsula Clean Energy and East Bay Community Energy for details on how the language in the PD should be changed to clarify the brown power true up. The CCAs described the on-going transparency issues in the ERRA.

SUMMARY:  On October 9, 2018, Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs, Kari Kloberdanz-Yu, Manager of Regulatory Relations, and Cyndee Fang, Manager of Customer Pricing, of Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), met with Joanna Gubman and Anand Durvasala, advisors to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco. Jason Houck, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, participated by telephone. SDG&E representatives discussed the unprecedented and sustained heatwave that hit San Diego this summer and the resulting high bills and customer complaints. SDG&E representatives informed that in an effort to respond to their customers concerns SDG&E is in the process of developing several potential solutions to provide customers with a better customer experience that may be filed with the CPUC in the near future. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On January 10, 2018, Nathanael Gonzalez, Senior Project Manager of Demand Response in Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), participated in the telephone conference with Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Acéves. In the teleconference also participated Jean Lamming, Neha Bazaj, and Whitney Richardson of the Energy Division, Karen Herter, the Energy Division’s residential energy efficiency consultant, and Andre Ramirez, Principal Advisor of Regulatory Affairs & Compliance, Eva Molnar, Senior Manager of Customer Programs & Services, Janet Zavala, Manager of Mass Market Demand Response, and David Kaintz, Senior Manager in Customer Programs & Services, for SCE. SCE representatives discussed its plans for a campaign to encourage low income customers to opt into Time-of-Use rates and to further discuss with SCE its limited Time-of-Use pilot with Nest including any lessons learned, barriers, and potential opportunities that could be applied in the context of the Demand Response (DR) Pilot initiative approved in the final decision on the DR 2018-2022 Funding Applications.

SUMMARY:  On January 4, 2017, Nathanael Gonzalez, Senior Project Manager of Demand Response in Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), participated in the telephone conference with Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Acéves. Also present were Jean Lamming of the Energy Division, Karen Herter, the Energy Division’s residential energy efficiency consultant, and Nathanael Gonzalez, Senior Project Manager of Demand Response in Regulatory Affairs, Davi Ibarra, Interim Manager for the Energy Savings Assistance Program, Janet Zavala, Manager of Mass Market Demand Response, and Robin Meidhof, Senior Attorney, for SCE. SCE representatives discussed Demand Response (DR) and how it can be used to help low-income customers, disadvantaged communities (DAC), and transmission-constrained local areas, particularly as customers are transitioned to time-of use rates. SCE raised the potential of working with Community Based Organizations (CBOs) in the DR Pilot. SCE suggested that it could use its expertise to identify low-income customers that could benefit by shifting their load, and further its education and outreach training with CBOs to help educate customers about time-of-use rates, thermostat settings, and available DR programs. SCE further discussed its commitment to align its marketing, education, and outreach campaigns across the low income, DR, and residential rate reform proceedings.

SUMMARY:  On October 9, 2018, Brian Prusnek, Director of Regulatory Affairs, Kari Kloberdanz-Yu, Manager of Regulatory Relations, and Cyndee Fang, Manager of Customer Pricing, of Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), met with Joanna Gubman and Anand Durvasala, advisors to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco. Jason Houck, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, participated by telephone. SDG&E representatives discussed the unprecedented and sustained heatwave that hit San Diego this summer and the resulting high bills and customer complaints. SDG&E representatives informed that in an effort to respond to their customers concerns SDG&E is in the process of developing several potential solutions to provide customers with a better customer experience that may be filed with the CPUC in the near future. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On April 11, 2018, Laura Genao, Managing Director of Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and on April 12 – with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Russell Garwacki, Director of Pricing, Design and Research, SCE, also attended the meeting of April 11th, and participated in the meeting of April 12th by telephone. Erin Pulgar, Senior Advisor of State Regulatory Operations, SCE, also participated in the meeting of April 12th by telephone. SCE’s representatives discussed SCE’s proposed TOU periods, specifically noting that SCE’s proposed TOU periods align with the state’s GHG goals and previous CPUC direction on TOU periods, and that an expeditious decision in this proceeding is necessary in order to enable the implementation of the proposed TOU periods. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

Notice of Ex Parte Communication of Decisionmaker. Shannon O’Rourke, Advisor to Commissioner Carla Peterman, noticed oral ex parte communication with Pacific Gas and Electric Company, on February 20, 2018 at 3:00 p.m.

SUMMARY:  On March 8, 2018, Matthew Plummer, Principal, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Candace Morey, advisor to Commissioner Guzman Aceves, and Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, in three separate meetings in San Francisco. At the meeting with Rachel Peterson also present were Jason Houck and Joanna Gubman, advisors to Cmmr. Randolph. Marino Monardi, Director, Structured Energy Transactions, and Charles Post, Manager, Energy Storage Strategy Implementation, for PG&E, attended all three meetings.  PG&E representatives discussed how its 2016-17 Energy Storage Solicitation and Related Cost Recovery application will meet the goals of Assembly Bill 2514. PG&E noted that the Llagas project is a multiuse project deferring a distribution reliability upgrade, with the costs being offset by wholesale market revenue. Finally, PG&E discussed the importance of storage for local sub-area reliability and meeting local capacity reliability needs.

EMAIL RULING GRANTING EXTENSION OF TIME FOR TESTIMONY AND REBUTTAL REGARDING NEW FEDERAL INCOME TAX LEGISLATION

SUMMARY:  On January 26, 2018, Phil Herrington, Senior Vice President of Transmission and Distribution, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), participated in a hearing attended by Cmmr. Picker before the California Senate Energy, Utilities, and Communications Subcommittee on Gas, Electric and Transportation Safety, at Santa Rosa City Hall. Elizaveta Malashenko, Director of the Commission’s Safety and Enforcement Division, and Nidhi Thakar, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, were also present. It is SCE’s understanding that Cmmr. Picker departed the hearing prior to Mr. Herrington’s panel. The hearing addressed utility wildfire prevention and response. Mr. Herrington provided an overview of SCE’s response to the recent wildfires and mudslide in California. Mr. Herrington stressed that it is imperative that the State improve fire safety by taking immediate action to implement clear State standards for critical infrastructure, developing smarter policies around building structures in high-risk fire areas, and executing a state-coordinated funding strategy to effectively address fire prevention and fire suppression. Mr. Herrington explained that when wildfires occur, the State needs a new approach to allocating costs so the financial risk is appropriately shared and insurance coverage remains affordable. Mr. Herrington also discussed that SCE uses a risk-based approach to assessing financial investments in its electric infrastructure that prioritizes safety.

RESPONSE TO SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON COMPANY’S MOTION TO STRIKE

SUMMARY:  On November 3, 2017, Andre Ramirez, Principal Advisor for Regulatory Affairs and Compliance for Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Lorene Miller, Managing Director, Customer Service Re-Platform Project (CS Re-Platform), and Laura Genao, Managing Director, Regulatory Affairs, for SCE. At the meeting, SCE representatives discussed the interplay between CS Re-Platform and SCE’s roll-out of residential default Time-Of-Use (TOU) rates. SCE addressed issues associated with the timing of SCE’s TOU roll-out and CS Re-Platform implementation. SCE discussed the potential Marketing, Education, and Outreach impacts of additional time required for SCE to fully complete the TOU roll-out, and SCE explained how the old and new systems can accommodate customers being transitioned at different times. SCE also discussed the impacts that certain elements of TOU roll-out (such as bill protection) can have on the timing of system implementation. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

Notice of Ex Parte Communication of Advisor.  David Gamson, Advisor to Commissioner Guzman Aceves, noticed oral and written ex parte communication with Southern California Edison Company, on October 13, 2017 at 1:00 p.m.
NOTICE OF EVIDENTIARY HEARING

Southern California Edison Company (SCE) noticed that it has been granted an ex parte meeting to discuss the interplay between SCE’s Customer Service Re-Platform Project and SCE’s roll-out of residential default Time- Of-Use.  The meeting will take place at an office located at 505 Van Ness Avenue, San Francisco.  The meeting is scheduled for Friday, November 3, 2017, at 3:30 p.m. with David Peck, Advisor to President Michael Picker.  Mr. Peck requested the meeting.  The following individuals will attend the meeting on behalf of SCE: Andre Ramirez, Principal Advisor for Regulatory Affairs and Compliance, Lorene Miller, Managing Director for CS Re-Platform, and Laura Genao, Managing Director for Regulatory Affairs.

Mr. Andre Ramirez, Principal Advisor, Regulatory Affairs and Compliance, Ms. Brandi Anderson, Principal Manager, Energy Programs, Mr. David Lotspeich, Senior Manager of Data, Analytics and Reporting, and Ms. Laura Genao, Managing Director, Regulatory Affairs. SUMMARY:  LATE FILED.  On April 26, 2017, Morad Fakhrai, Director of Public Works of the City of Hayward (City), met with David Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present was Kevin Briggs, Acting Assistant City Engineer for the City.  City staff discussed the proposed decision (PD) and the alternate proposed decision (APD) as they relate to the Rule 20A program.  City staff agrees with the determination in both decisions that Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) should create a balancing account for Rule 20A funds and that an audit of PG&E's Rule 20A program is necessary.  City staff expressed support for the determination in the PD that the Rule 20A allocations should return to the 2010 level.  City staff disapproved the determination in the APD that the Rule 20A allocation should remain at the 2011 GRC determined levels but later during the meeting agreed that a return to a "tariff based calculation" of the allocation level would also be supportable.  City staff stressed its opinion that undergrounded electrical facilities are safer than overhead electrical facilities.  City staff discussed the difficulty that reduced allocation levels create and how very difficult it is for cities to accumulate enough work credits to include undergrounding with any significant Capital Improvement Project.

SUMMARY:  On January 26, 2018 Pat Hogan, Senior Vice President, Electric Operations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), testified on behalf of PG&E at a public hearing before the Energy, Utilities and Communications Subcommittee on Gas, Electric and Transportation Safety at Santa Rosa City Hall.  Cmmr. Picker also testified at the hearing, but was not present during Mr. Hogan’s testimony. However, PG&E believes that Nidhi Thakar, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, was present when Mr. Hogan made his opening remarks. The topic of the hearing was wildfire prevention and response. Mr. Hogan began his opening remarks expressing his heartfelt sympathies to the thousands of families affected by last year’s fires. Mr. Hogan stated that in light of this reality, it is incumbent on us all to work together, to continue to evolve our prevention and response efforts and to develop best practices and solutions for the evolving conditions of our new normal. Mr. Hogan noted that in defining best practices, we need to keep in mind that each utility’s service territory has different risks, based on environment, weather, vegetation, terrain, population density and other factors, and what may be an appropriate practice for one utility may not be for another. Mr. Hogan described PG&E’s key prevention and response programs. Mr. Hogan closed by emphasizing that PG&E is ready to work with stakeholders. Mr. Hogan’s full opening comments are available at https://youtu.be/gfp6PfjKDio.

SUMMARY:  On December 16, 2015, Robert Kenney, Vice President, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in San Francisco.  Also present was Fong Wan, Senior Vice President, Energy Policy and Procurement, for PG&E. Kenney and Wan expressed support for the proposed decision of Administrative Law Judge Wilson in PG&E's 2016 Energy Resource Recovery Account proceeding.  Kenney and Wan expressed concern about some of the public misinformation in articles, editorials, letters and ex parte communications with the CPUC, and reiterated that the PCIA is intended to protect bundled customers. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  O on December 16, 2015, Elizabeth Kelly, Legal Director of Marin Clean Energy, sent a written ex parte communication via e-mail to Cmmrs. Picker, Florio, Sandoval, Peterman, and Randolph.  Also copied on the letter were Nicolas Chaset, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Sepideh Khosrowjah, advisor to Cmmr. Florio,  Ditas Katague, advisor to Cmmr. Sandoval, David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. The email communication is provided in Attachment A to this Notice.

column5: City and County of San Francisco
column6: SUMMARY:  On December 15, 2015, Barbara Hale, Assistant General Manager for Power, the City and County of San Francisco (CCSF), met with Leuwam Tesfai, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco.  Also present were Emily Lam, Director of Policy and Legislative Affairs, and James Hendry, Acting Manager for Legislative and Regulatory Affairs - Power, for CCSF. CCSF representatives discussed the increase in Pacific Gas & Electric's (PG&E) Power Charge Indifference Account (PCIA) rates. CCSF representatives described the effect of such a significant increase on CCSF's Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) program, Clean Power SF.  CCSF representatives expressed support for the proposal of Marin Clean Energy to cap the level of PCIA increase; create a balancing account to track balances; and initiate a proceeding to examine the methodology and accuracy of the PCIA forecasts.  CCSF representatives stated its concerns about the lack of transparency, independent third-party review, and access to confidential data that make it difficult for CCAs to evaluate the accuracy of PG&E's PCIA calculations.  CCSF representatives urged the Commission to reconsider and re-evaluate the PCIA methodology. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On December 14, 2015, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, Marin Clean Energy, sent an e-mail to Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio. A copy of the email communication is attached to the notice.

column5: City and County of San Francisco
column6: SUMMARY:  On December 10, 2015, Barbara Hale, Assistant General Manager for Power, the City and County of San Francisco (City), met with met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Emily Lam, Director of Policy and Legislative Affairs, and James Hendry, Acting Manager for Legislative and Regulatory Affairs - Power, for the City.  The City representatives discussed the increase in Pacific Gas & Electric's (PG&E) Power Charge Indifference Account (PCIA) rates. The City representatives of San Francisco described, among other things, the City's support for the proposal of Marin Clean Energy to cap the level of PCIA increase, create a balancing account to track balances, and initiate a proceeding to examine the methodology and accuracy of the PCIA forecasts.  The City representatives expressed the City's concerns about the lack of transparency, independent third-party review, and access to confidential data that make it difficult for CCAs to evaluate the accuracy of PG&E's PCIA calculations.  The City representatives stated the need for the Commission to reconsider and re-evaluate the PCIA methodology. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

column6: Reply comments on Proposed Decision.

SUMMARY:  On December 1, 2015, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, Marin Clean Energy (MCE), had a teleconference with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio.  Scott Blaising, outside counsel for MCE, also participated.  During the teleconference, MCE's representatives requested that the Proposed Decision in this proceeding be modified to associate the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) workshop with a proceeding where an official record could be developed. MCE proposed to hold the workshop either through the second phase of the 2016 PG&E ERRA proceeding or another proceeding, including the currently open second phase of the 2015 PG&E ERRA proceeding. MCE's representatives also proposed changes to the Proposed Decision regarding the PCIA rate for 2016.

SUMMARY:  On September 11, 2015, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Waen discussed the history of and potential future for Commission policy reform relating to both the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) and the Cost Allocation Mechanism (CAM).  Waen stated MCE's belief of the continued need for reform to the policies relating to both the PCIA and the CAM. Waen also explained the need for each of the potential areas of PCIA- and CAM-related policy reform that MCE hopes to see scoped within the next Long-Term Procurement Plan proceeding cycle. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Application of Pacific Gas and Electric Company for Adoption of Electric Revenue Requirements and Rates Associated with its 2016 Energy Resource Recovery Account (ERRA) and Generation Non-Bypassable Charges Forecast and Greenhouse Gas Forecast Revenue and Reconciliation (U39E).

SUMMARY:  on December 15, 2015, Sloan Bailey, Board Member for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Leuwam Tesfai, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco.  Also present was Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for MCE. MCE's representatives commended the Commission for tying the proposed Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) workshop to a proceeding where an official record could be developed. MCE's representatives proposed changes to the Proposed Decision regarding the PCIA rate for 2016. In particular, MCE requested that the increase be limited to 15% of the current PCIA rate and that a balancing account be used to isolate the remaining balance until the Commission reaches a decision in an ultimate proceeding for PCIA reform. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On December 16, 2015, Robert Kenney, Vice President, CPUC Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), sent by electronic mail a letter to Cmmrs. Picker, Florio, Sandoval, Peterman, and Randolph. Hard copies were also delivered at the Commission offices in San Francisco. Copies of the letter were also sent to Nicolas Chaset, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Sepideh Khosrowjah, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, Ditas Katague, advisor to Cmmr. Sandoval, David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. In the letter, Kenney urges the Commission to adopt ALJ Wilson's well-reasoned proposed decision in PG&E's 2016 ERRA proceeding. Copies of the e-mail transmittal and letter are attached to the notice.

SUMMARY:  On December 11, 2015, Geof Syphers, Chief Executive Officer for Sonoma Clean Power, sent an e-mail communication to Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio. The email requested discussion of two tools that could be used for transparency and planning purposes during the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment workshop scheduled in 2016. A copy of the email is attached to the notice.

SUMMARY:  On December 14, 2015, Stephanie Chen, Energy & Telecommunications Policy Director of the Greenlining Institute, sent by electronic mail a letter to Cmmrs. Picker, Sandoval, Florio, Peterman, and Randolph.  Copies of the correspondence were also sent to Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, Amy Baker, advisor to Cmmr. Sandoval, Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Leuwam Tesfai, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph.  A copy of the correspondence is attached to the notice.

column5: Lean Energy US,City of Davis,City of San Mateo,San Mateo County
column6: [Joint] SUMMARY:   On December 9, 2015, Dave Pine, San Mateo County Board of Supervisors, met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in two separate meetings in San Francisco.  Also present were Rick Bonilla, City of San Mateo City Council, Robb Davis, Mayor of the City of Davis, and Shawn Marshall, Executive Director of LEAN Energy US (LEAN); and Kim Malcolm, Regulatory Manager for LEAN, participated by telephone. The parties' representatives discussed the plans of several California communities to develop community choice aggregation (CCA) programs and how Pacific Gas and Electric Company's proposed Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) increases would affect the viability of such programs. Pine, Davis and Bonilla described their plans for CCA development in their respective communities, including ancillary programs that might be affected by a doubling of the PCIA.  The parties' representatives requested that the Proposed Decision in this proceeding be modified. The parties' representatives stated support for a third party audit of the PCIA costs. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

Administrative Law Judge’s Ruling resolving confidentiality claims raised by Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Southern California Edison Company, and San Diego Gas & Electric Company as to distribution system planning data ordered by Decision (D.) 17-09-026 and D.18-12-004.

SUMMARY:  On November 29, 2018, Rick Umoff, Regulatory Counsel and California Director, State Affairs for the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA), Sky Stanfield, outside counsel of the Interstate Renewable Energy Council, Inc. and Sahm White, Director, Policy & Economic Analysis for Clean Coalition, met with Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Representatives from the California Energy Storage Alliance, the California Solar and Storage Association, Stem, Community Solar Access, Tesla, Inc., Sunrun Inc. and SEIA participated in the meeting by way of teleconference. The parties representatives discussed their concerns regarding the position that has been taken by the investor owned utilities (IOU) regarding the confidentiality of distribution system planning data. The parties representatives discussed how such a broad interpretation of what is confidential makes it very difficult to craft a non-disclosure agreement that creates workable provisions for parties to operate under, especially as it exposes the recipient of information to potential liability for revealing information that is in fact already in the public domain. The parties representatives noted that with the IOUs being under a Commission directive to release the Integrate Capacity Analysis maps and data by the end of the year, the need to reach resolution on the confidentiality issue was pressing.

column6: JOINT; SUMMARY:  On October 18, 2018, Robert Kenney, Vice President, Regulatory Affairs, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), and Laura Genao, Managing Director, Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE) (collectively, the Joint IOUs), met with Cmmr. Picker and Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Gabe Petlin and Dina Mackin of the Energy Division, Daniel Bout of the Safety and Enforcement Division, and Christopher Nolan of the Legal Division; and Roy Kuga, Vice President, Integrated Grid and Innovation, Bernard Cowens, Vice President and Chief Security Officer, and James Murphy, Senior Director, Corporate Security, of PG&E; and Erik Takeyasu, Managing Director of Integrated Innovation and Modernization of SCE. The Joint IOUs representatives discussed security issues regarding the public availability of the Solar Photovoltaic (PV) and Renewable Auction Mechanism (RAM) maps. PG&E stated that it has been observing cyber security threats to its PV RAM map data which has been increasing since the issue was first deliberated upon in 2011. The Joint IOUs noted that they were interested in protecting the grid by limiting bad actors from obtaining the information and had no intention of limiting access to verified good actors. The Joint IOUs proposed to require users of the maps to register on a secure web portal and sign a non-disclosure agreement which does not deviate from the norm adopted by the Commission and other stakeholders for other security-sensitive and confidential information. The Joint IOUs noted that restricting access to PV Maps would be consistent with other more recent actions taken by the Commission and the approach by other state and federal agencies. The Joint IOUs sought updated protocols from the CPUC contemplating cyber and physical security risks and proposed a short-term interim solution.

Also present were Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor, and Christopher Myers and Christian Knierim, Public Utilities Regulatory Analysts, for the ORA. ORA raised its concerns with the alternate proposed Decision Approving the Results of Southern California Edison Company’s Second Preferred Resources Pilot Procurement (APD) issued in A.16-11-002. ORA emphasized that unlike the APD, past Commission decisions considered executed contracts in determining authorization for new procuring new resources and that the proposed agreements would not eliminate the need to use existing gas fired generation. SUMMARY:  On April 19, 2018, Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor of the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and on April 20, 2018, with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. At the meetings also present were Christian Knierim, Public Utilities Regulatory Analyst, and Matt Miley, Staff Attorney, for the ORA. At the meeting with Candace Morey also present was Christopher Myers, Public Utilities Regulatory Analyst, for the ORA. During both meetings, ORA discussed the proposed Decision Denying the Application of Southern California Edison (PD), which was issued in Application (A.) 16-11-002. ORA noted that Southern California Edison Company (SCE) asks the Commission to take judicial notice of the California Energy Commission’s (CEC) California Energy Demand (CED) Update Forecast 2016-2027 and CED [Revised] Forecast 2018-2030 for the alleged factual truth that the PRP RFO 2 resources may be needed to address a load increase of approximately 720 MW in the Western Los Angeles (LA) Basin by 2021. ORA asserted that that factual matter is in dispute and by law, judicial notice should not be granted. ORA pointed out that the CEC’s CED forecasts do not focus on the Western LA Basin, but rather the entire LA Basin. ORA discussed relevant information regarding one of the contracts that SCE claims will support its Distribution Resources Plan (DRP) Demonstration Projects (Demo) C in Rulemaking 14-08-013 et al. ORA explained that the record does not support the purported viability of one of the contracts for the purposes of Demo C. In the meeting with Ehren Seybert, ORA also discussed several claims made in a letter in support of SCE’s Application that was served on the service list for A.16-11-002 on April 20, 2018 by the non-party Center for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Technologies.

column6: [By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On November 1, 2018, Rachel Peterson, Anand Durvasula, and Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, met in San Francisco with representative(s) of Sunrun Inc.

SUMMARY:  On November 1, 2018, Audrey Lee, Vice President of Energy Services; Alex McDonough, Vice President of Policy; and Marc Kolb, Consultant from Sunrun Inc. (Sunrun), met with Rachel Peterson, Anand Durvasula, and Joanna Gubman, advisors to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco. Sunrun representatives emphasized that behind-the-meter (BTM) storage providers can benefit all utility customers by providing substantial clean, local and customer-driven capacity in ways that can meet various grid services needs such as resource adequacy (RA) and distribution deferral. Sunrun explained that several policy barriers are restraining the ability for this capacity to be cost-effectively provided to the market. Sunrun clarified that the nearest term way to allow for BTM storage systems to be aggregated and deliver additional valuable energy services is to ensure that exports from BTM storage systems qualify for RA capacity credit. Sunrun supported collaboration between the Commission and the California Independent System Operation (CAISO) to modify the CAISO’s Proxy Demand Response market mechanism to allow for exports or changes in the RA rules. Sunrun stated that it would also support load modification constructs that would allow exports to reduce a load serving entity’s RA obligation. Sunrun generally discussed other concerns encountered in recent grid services solicitations.

At the meeting also present were Aaron Stanton for IREC; Polly Shaw for Stem; Jason Keyes on behalf of JTN Energy; Laura Fedoruk for SunRun; Rachel Bird for Borrego Solar; Brandon Smithwood for the Coalition for Community Solar Access; Jeff Lounsberry for CalCom Energy; Sahm White for the Clean Coalition; and Rick Umoff for Solar Energy Industries Association. IREC representatives discussed the importance of restoring the Photovoltaic Renewable Auction Mechanism maps in order to ensure distributed energy resources customers are able to select appropriate locations for their projects. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Notice of Ex Parte Communication of Decisionmaker. Jason Houck, Advisor to Commissioner Randolph, noticed oral and written ex parte communications with the Office of Ratepayer Advocates, on April 17, 2018 at 11:00 a.m.

SUMMARY:  On April 12, 2018, Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA) met with Dave Peck, advisor to Cmmr. Picker; on April 13, 2018 -- with Yuliya Shmidt and Sandy Goldberg, advisors to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen; and on April 17, 2018 -- with Jason Houck, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco.  Also present were Christopher Myers and Christian Knierim, Public Utilities Regulatory Analysts, and Matt Miley, Staff Attorney, for the ORA. ORA discussed the proposed Decision Denying the Application of Southern California Edison (PD). ORA stated its support for the PD. ORA also discussed two Notices of Ex Parte Communication that were recently filed in A.16-11-002 by entities that are not parties to that proceeding: (1) the notice filed by Convergent Energy and Power, LP on April 2, 2018 (Convergent Notice), and (2) the notice filed by Swell Energy Inc. on April 3, 2018 (Swell Notice). ORA emphasized that the Convergent Notice and the Swell Notice do not indicate that their respective “Comments” on the Proposed Decision were not accepted by the Commission’s Docket Office and, therefore, are not part of the record of the proceeding. ORA stated that it finds this activity to be misleading to the Commission and the public. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On January 31, 2018, at 11:30 a.m., Dawn Anaiscourt, Director, CPUC Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Sergio Islas, PRP Project Manager, and Jason Edwards, Principal Manager of Valuation, for SCE. SCE discussed the PRP RFO 2. SCE also discussed the relationship between the Swell contract executed in the PRP RFO 2 and SCE’s Demonstration Project C. SCE filed this notice because Demonstration Project C is an issue in Track 2 of the DRP OIR. SCE did not provide three-day advance notice in the Distribution Resources Plan Order Instituting Rulemaking (OIR) because it did not anticipate addressing substantive issues in Track 2 of the DRP OIR, which is categorized as ratesetting.

Mason III is assigned as the Administrative Law Judge for the quasi-legislative portions of the proceeding and is the presiding officer for the ratesetting portions of the proceeding. SUMMARY:  On December 20, 2017, Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor, the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Rajan Mutialu, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Christopher Myers and Christian Knierim, Public Utilities Regulatory Analysts, and Matt Miley, Staff Attorney, for the ORA. ORA discussed Southern California Edison Company’s (SCE) Preferred Resources Pilot (PRP) Request for Offer (RFO) 2 (PRP RFO 2) and the Distribution Resources Plan (DRP) Demonstration (Demo) Projects C and D. ORA noted that the cumulative cost of the PRP RFO 2 contracts that SCE proposes to use for its DRP Demo C is well beyond the procurement cost cap that the Commission instituted in Decision (D.) 17-02-007 for SCE’s DRP Demo C. ORA noted that the cumulative cost of the PRP RFO 2 contracts that SCE proposes to use for its DRP Demo D is significant, and SCE’s request is therefore inconsistent with the Commission’s determination in D.17-02-007. A written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On November 29, 2017, Dawn Anaiscourt, Director of CPUC Regulatory Affairs of Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Rajan Mutialu, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Diana Genasci, Principal Advisor, Regulatory Affairs, for SCE.  SCE representatives discussed the PRP RFO2 proceeding and the related Distributed Resource Plan (DRP) Demonstration C and D projects. SCE noted that there were several contracts in the PRP RFO2 application SCE planned to use in its DRP demonstration projects. Specifically, for Demonstration C, designed to test the locational net benefits analysis methodology, SCE stated that it believes successful implementation of the project relies upon timely approval of a certain PRP contract. For Demonstration D, which is designed to study high DER penetration levels, SCE stated that it intends to use the PRP contracts to significantly augment the DER penetration in the study area. Finally, SCE stated that it believed leveraging PRP RFO2 contracts to reduce DRP procurement needs was the right thing to do, and noted the Commission’s own expression of appreciation for this approach in the DRP Track 2 Demo C and D decision issued in February.

SUMMARY:  On November 2, 2017, Dawn Anaiscourt, Director of Regulatory Affairs for Southern California Edison Company (SCE), sent an email to Gabriel Petlin of the Energy Division. The e-mail was also addressed to Rachel McMahon and Marc Monbouquette of the Energy Division. The communication concerned Application (A.) 16-11-002, the Application of SCE for approval of its Second Preferred Resources Pilot Request for Offers (PRP RFO 2 Application). This email stated that SCE believes the timing of the issuance of a decision in the PRP RFO 2 Application will likely have an impact on SCE’s Demonstration Project C. A copy of the e-mail is attached to the notice.

SUMMARY:  On April 4, 2018 Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor, the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and on April 5, 2018, with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Christopher Myers and Christian Knierim, Public Utilities Regulatory Analysts, and Matt Miley, Staff Attorney, for the ORA.  ORA representatives stated its support for the proposed Decision Denying the Application of Southern California Edison (PD). ORA also discussed two Notices of Ex Parte Communication that were recently filed in A.16-11-002 by entities that are not parties to that proceeding: (1) the notice filed by Convergent Energy and Power, LP on April 2, 2018 (Convergent Notice), and (2) the notice filed by Swell Energy Inc. on April 3, 2018 (Swell Notice). ORA noted that the Convergent Notice and the Swell Notice both contain attachments that are formally captioned as “Comments” on the PD. ORA emphasized that the Convergent Notice and the Swell Notice do not indicate that their respective “Comments” on the Proposed Decision were not accepted by the Commission’s Docket Office and, therefore, are not part of the record. ORA stated that it finds this activity to be misleading to the Commission and the public.  Written material, attached to the notice, was used.
