SUMMARY:  On January 24, 2018, Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Christopher Myers and Christian Knierim, public utilities regulatory analysts, and Matt Miley, staff attorney, for the ORA. ORA discussed Southern California Edison Company’s (SCE) Preferred Resources Pilot (PRP) Request for Offer (RFO) 2 (PRP RFO 2) and the Distribution Resources Plan (DRP) Demonstration (Demo) Projects C and D. Among other things, ORA noted that the cumulative cost of the PRP RFO 2 contracts that SCE proposes to use for its DRP Demo C is well beyond the procurement cost cap that the Commission instituted in Decision (D.) 17-02-007 for SCE’s DRP Demo C. ORA noted that the cumulative cost of the PRP RFO 2 contracts that SCE proposes to use for its DRP Demo D is significant, and SCE’s request is therefore inconsistent with (1) the Commission’s determination in D.17-02-007 and (2) SCE’s June 17, 2016 comments in the DRP proceeding that it does not anticipate requiring additional procurements to support Demo D. ORA pointed out that in D.17-02-007 the Commission rejected SCE’s request to extend its Demo D schedule to accommodate PRP RFO 2 resources.  Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On January 17, 2018, Matt Miley, Staff Attorney for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Karin Hieta, Program and Project Supervisor, and Christopher Myers and Christian Knierim, Public Utilities Regulatory Analysts, for the ORA. ORA discussed Southern California Edison Company’s (SCE) Preferred Resources Pilot (PRP) Request for Offer (RFO) 2 (PRP RFO 2) and the Distribution Resources Plan (DRP) Demonstration (Demo) Projects C and D. ORA noted that the cumulative cost of the PRP RFO 2 contracts that SCE proposes to use for its DRP Demo C is well beyond the procurement cost cap that the Commission instituted in Decision (D.) 17-02-007 for SCE’s DRP Demo C. ORA noted that the cumulative cost of the PRP RFO 2 contracts that SCE proposes to use for its DRP Demo D is significant, and SCE’s request is therefore inconsistent with (1) the Commission’s determination in D.17-02-007 that SCE should not incur additional procurement costs for Demo D, and (2) SCE’s June 17, 2016 comments in the DRP proceeding that it does not anticipate requiring additional procurements to support Demo D. ORA pointed out that in D.17-02-007 the Commission rejected SCE’s request to extend its Demo D schedule to accommodate PRP RFO 2 resources, and that SCE’s statement in its December 4, 2017 ex parte notice that “one PRP contract could enable SCE to study a circuit with 160% [Distributed Energy Resource] penetration” is unsupported by the record evidence. Finally, ORA noted that (1) the Commission provided the utilities the opportunity to increase their DRP Demo cost caps and SCE does not appear to have requested a cost increase for Demo C or D, and (2) SCE proposed and the Commission, in D.17-02-007, authorized the utilities to procure resources for the DRP Demos and request approval of the resources via a Tier 3 advice letter process. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On July 21, 2017, Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco.. Mark Esguerra, Director, Integrated Grid Planning, PG&E, was also in attendance.  Esguerra stated that PG&E supports the development of distributed energy resources in disadvantaged communities, and has pilots in these areas. Esguerra further stated that PG&E will look for further opportunities, within pilots and outside of pilots, to deploy these resources in constrained areas in the Central Valley and within Disadvantaged Communities. Dietz stated that PG&E’s NEM 2.0 Phase 2 proposal, Solar Care Plus, would result in the deployment of additional solar projects in disadvantaged communities, would provide a discount to participants, and is well-suited to the challenges in these communities.

The Utility Reform Network (TURN) noticed an oral ex-parte communication that occurred on June 28, 2016, at approximately 9:30 a.m.  Marcel Hawiger, staff attorney with TURN, initiated a conversation with Sean Simon, energy advisor to Commissioner Liane Randolph. The conversation lasted approximately 2 minutes and took place in the Commission’s Auditorium. Mr. Hawiger stated that the total cost of the demonstration C, D, and E projects for all three utilities was about $67 million, of which $47 million was requested by SCE. Mr. Hawiger stated that TURN was concerned these projects duplicated work already funded through other research grants and awards.

SUMMARY:  On June 1, 2016, Jamie Fine, Senior Economist, Environmental Defense Fund (EDF), had an impromptu conversation with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio during their morning commute on the ferry from Alameda to San Francisco.  Dr. Fine discussed broadly the progress made by the Integrated Capacity Analysis (ICA)/Local Net Benefits Analysis (LNBA) working groups, the fact that the working groups need to be diligent in following processes for establishing “consensus” positions that allow enough time for meaningful comment by stakeholders, and the fact that utility methodologies for ICA and LNBA need further refinement. In addition, Dr. Fine touched on EDF’s work in Fresno with the Rocky Mountain Institute Electricity Lab, Integrated Distributed Energy Resource utility revenue pilot and EDF’s alternative to that pilot, and the recent ruling in New York on utility business models.

The Utility Reform Network (TURN) noticed an oral ex-parte communication that occurred on June 28, 2016, at approximately 12:20 p.m.  Matthew Tisdale, energy advisor to Commissioner Mike Florio initiated a conversation with Marcel Hawiger, staff attorney for TURN. The conversation lasted approximately 40 minutes and took place in the Commission’s cafeteria. Also present was Eric Borden of TURN.  The discussion was regarding the existing 3 GW of distributed solar generation and the need to either review proposed projects in detail, including through evidentiary hearings, or else to impose cost limits on authorizations for demonstration projects to prevent unnecessary spending.

SUMMARY: On July 29 and 30, 2015, representatives of Southern California Edison Company (SCE) and Edison International had ex parte communications with Cmmr. Picker.  On July 29th, Ronald Nichols, Senior Vice President of Regulatory Affairs of Southern California Edison Company (SCE), had a brief discussion with Cmmr. Picker at the event related to Weisenmiller's re-appointment as Chair of the California Energy Commission held at The Firehouse Restaurant, in Sacramento.  Nichols expressed support for the general concept of an exchange of ideas between the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) and the New York State Public Service Commission (NYSPSC) with respect to the addition of distributed energy resources to the distribution system. On July 30th, Theodore Craver, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Edison International, participated in a teleconference initiated by Audrey Zibelman, Commissioner and Chair of the NYSPSC.  Cmmr. Picker participated in the conference. Peter Fox Penner, Principal of The Brattle Group, John McAvoy, Chief Executive Officer and President of Consolidated Edison also participated. Craver affirmed support for the general concept of an exchange of ideas between the CPUC and NYSPSC with respect to the addition of distributed energy resources to the distribution system.

SUMMARY:  On April 11, 2016, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was CC Song, Regulatory Analyst for MCE. MCE requested clarity on the procedural next steps for this proceeding. MCE stated the need for the Commission to create a tracking and reporting process for voluntarily adopted energy storage devices that receive Self-Generation Incentive Program funds within Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) service areas. MCE also requested the Commission to provide guidance in Track 2 of the proceeding on the storage procurement targets of emerging CCAs.

column6: [Joint;] SUMMARY:  On January 12, 2016, Ms. Sue Mara, Principal with RTOAdvisors, L.L.C., and consultant to The Alliance for Retail Energy Markets1 (AReM) and Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), met with Sepideh Khosrowjah, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in San Francisco.  Greg Bass, Director, Noble Americas Energy Solutions LLC, and Cynthia Clark, Associate Wholesale Electricity Program Manager, University of California, Office of the President, attended the meeting by telephone. Mara, Bass and Clark explained that AReM and DACC strongly objected to the December 15, 2015 proposed decision's (PD) determination that the investor-owned utilities (IOUs) would be permitted to count all of the energy storage projects funded partially through the Self-Generation Incentive Program. Mara, Bass and Clark also discussed the PD's determination that the load-serving entity of the customers installing energy storage projects should retain the storage credits.  Mara, Bass and Clark stated AReM and DACC have proposed that the customer that invested in the energy storage project be able to assign the energy storage procurement "credit" to the LSE as they choose.  Mara discussed the PD's determinations regarding the Power Charge Indifference Amount (PCIA). Mara explained that all PCIA policy issues should be addressed uniformly in Track 2 in this rulemaking.  Mara explained that the PD erred in stating that the Commission would determine the PCIA cost recovery period for the IOUs' 2014 energy storage solicitations in the separate proceedings.  Mara requested that the PD be revised.
for Party Status

SUMMARY: On January 6, 2016, Sue Mara, Principal with RTOAdvisors, L.L.C., and consultant to The Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and?Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco.  Greg Bass, Director, Noble Americas Energy Solutions LLC., attended the meetings by telephone.  Mara and Bass explained that AReM and direct access customers (DAC) strongly objected to the Proposed Decision's (PD) determination that the investor-owned utilities (IOUs) would be permitted to count all of the energy storage projects funded partially through the Self-Generation Incentive Program.  Mara and Bass discussed the PD's determination that the load-serving entity of the customers installing energy storage projects should retain the storage credits.  Mara and Bass stated that AReM and the DAC Coalition have proposed that the customer that invested in the energy storage project be able to assign the energy storage procurement "credit" to the LSE. Mara and Bass discussed the PD's determination regarding the Power Charge Indifference Amount (PCIA), and explained that all PCIA policy issues should be addressed uniformly in Track 2 in this rulemaking. Mara explained that the PD erred in stating that the Commission would determine the PCIA cost recovery period for the IOUs' 2014 energy storage solicitations in the separate proceedings addressing the IOUs' applications.  Mara requested that the PD be revised to correct that error.

SUMMARY:  On January 4, 2016, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was CC Song, Regulatory Analyst for MCE.  MCE representatives voiced concerns regarding the language within the Proposed Decision which would continue to limit SGIP-funded ES deployment to only being countable towards the Investor-Owned Utilities' (IOUs) ES procurement targets. MCE expressed its concern that the continued prohibition of Community Choice Aggregator's (CCAs) abilities to count SGIP-funded ES deployment towards their procurement targets, would likely lead to stagnation in the development of customer-side ES market segment. MCE reminded the Commission of MCE's collaboration with the College of Marin and Tesla Motors Inc. to install on-site ES. MCE representatives stated this resource will be located on the premises of a MCE customer within MCE's service territory, yet MCE is not presently able to claim credit for the development of this resource towards its ES procurement target, per Decision 13-10-040. MCE staff questioned whether there may still be a middle-ground solution that would allow both IOUs and CCAs to count of SGIP-funded ES resources towards their procurement targets.

SUMMARY:  On July 21, 2015, Steve Berberich, Chief Executive Officer and President of the California Independent System Operator Corporation (CAISO), sent a letter to all five Commissioners and their respective Chiefs of Staff and Energy Advisors. Although the letteraddressed R.13-12-010, the CAISO files the instant notice because the Scoping Memo in this proceeding specifically seeks to evaluate "whether new information and/or evolving circumstances exist such that the Commission should revisit previously excluded energy storage technologies such as vehicle-grid integration and pumped hydro storage."  A copy of the letter is attached to the notice.

SUMMARY:  On July 9, 2018, Radu Ciupagea, Project Coordinator, and Zhen Zhang, Attorney, for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco. ORA discussed the May 31, 2018, revised Proposed Decision (RPD) and specifically the Mountainview Generating Station outage, the reasonable manager standard, and Southern California Edison’s (SCE) non-delegable duty for harm caused by its contractor. ORA representatives stated that the RPD correctly holds SCE liable for the negligence of its contractors. ORA stated its support for the RPD’s disallowance regarding the Mountainview outage. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On December 22, 2017, Radu Ciupagea, Project Coordinator for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Rajan Mutialu, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were Mea Halperin, Analyst, and Zhen Zhang, attorney, for the ORA. ORA representatives stated that the revised proposed decision (PD) correctly holds Southern California Edison (SCE) liable for the negligence of its contractors. ORA representatives also stated its support for the revised PD’s disallowance regarding the Mountainview outage. The ORA noted that the revised PD errs in finding as reasonable SCE’s actions with regards to CAISO commitment cost calculation errors as well as in finding that SCE does not have to show it produced an accurate forecast to meet the Standard of Conduct. The ORA contended that the revised PD errs in concluding that a one-time independent review of SCE’s hydro, price, and load forecasting and modeling tools is unnecessary. ORA argued that the revised PD errs in failing to reflect SCE’s agreement to provide to ORA the same power entity reports SCE submits to the California Air Resource Board on June 1. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On June 27, 2018, Radu Ciupagea, Project Coordinator of the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and with David Peck, Advisor to President Michael Picker, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present at the first meeting were Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division and Diana Lee, attorney for the ORA, and at the second meeting - Marion Peleo, attorney for the ORA. The ORA discussed the May 31, 2018 revised proposed decision, in particular the Mountain View Generating Station outage, the reasonable manager standard, and Southern California Edison’s (SCE) nondelegable duty for harm caused by its contractor. ORA indicated that the revised proposed decision correctly holds SCE liable for the negligence of its contractors, and that ORA supports the revised proposed decision’s disallowance regarding the Mountain View outage. At the second meeting, ORA representatives also stated that, as discussed in ORA’s briefs, SCE should provide additional metrics or a supplemental narrative to demonstrate the accuracy of its load and price forecasts, and that there should be an independent review of SCE’s forecasting and modeling tools. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

Certificate of Service of Three-Day Notice of Grant of Request for Individual Ex Parte Meeting.

SUMMARY:  On December 22, 2017, Laura Genao, Managing Director of Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), met with Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present were Mitchell Shapson of the Commission’s Legal Division, and Russell Archer, Senior Attorney, for SCE.  SCE’s representatives discussed the Revised Proposed Decision (Revised PD) pending in this proceeding. SCE’s representatives expressed concerns with the procedural fashion in which Revised PD was issued. SCE also discussed how the Revised PD’s findings regarding the Record Period outage at Mountainview Generating Station are inconsistent with previous Commission precedent and could have negative unintentional consequences if not modified. SCE noted that for Utility-Owned Generation outages the appropriate standard of review is the reasonable manager standard, not a perfection standard. SCE also observed that the line of cases imposing liability on utilities for the actions of their contractors beginning with the Snyder decision was limited to instances where there were violations of non-delegable safety-related duties. SCE explained that Commission rules do not provide that a utility must be held vicariously liable for mistakes made by its vendor.

[Pursuant to D14-11-041] SUMMARY:  On May 12, 2015, Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) met with Edward Randolph, Director of the Energy Division, at the Commission offices.  Also present were Gurbux Kahlon, Branch Manager, Jonathon Tom, Supervisor, and William Macguire, Analyst, for the Energy Division; and Randall Litteneker, Attorney, Law Department, Diana Genasci, Expert Case Manager, Regulatory Affairs, Christopher Smith, Principal, Energy Supply, and David Gutierrez, Principal, Alisha Ferrone, Expert Account Manager, Rene Mendoza, Expert Account Manager, Daniela Aceves, Expert Marketing Strategist, Andrew Au, Expert Product Manager, and Michael Tang, Supervisor, Customer Care, for PG&E; and representatives from Marin Clean Energy, Sonoma Clean Power, Lancaster Choice Energy, and Southern California Edison Company.  Litteneker stated that, generally speaking, the amount of a General Rate Case (GRC) ask is within the scope of GRC Phase I, and the allocation to different types of charges, for instance for generation or distribution, is made in Phase II.  Littenecker further stated that a settlement of the Phase II issues is pending before the Commission.

SUMMARY:  On December 17, 2014, Nora Sheriff, counsel to the Energy Producers and Users Coalition (EPUC), met with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in San Francisco. Sheriff stated that the record lacked sufficient evidence to justify the Alternate Proposed Decision's (Alternate) approval of an Option R rate option for E-19 and E-20 customers. Ms. Sheriff stated EPUC's support for the Proposed Decision's (PD) rejection of the boutique Option R rate and recommended adoption of the PD. Sheriff reiterated the recommendation in EPUC testimony that the Commission consider establishing a separate customer class for customers with solar Page 2 -EPUC generation, with their own allocation of costs and rate design specific to such customers' cost-causative characteristics. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

column6: Notice of Ex Parte Communications. Center for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Technologies noticed separate oral and written ex parte communications with Sean Simon, Chief of Staff to Commissioner Rechtschaffen; with Leuwam Tesfai, Energy Advisor to Commissioner Randolph; and with Candace Morey, Legal Advisor to Commissioner Guzman Aceves, respectively at different times on June 23, 2017.

SUMMARY:  On June 22, 2017, Sara Steck Myers, attorney for CPower, EnerNOC, Inc., and EnergyHub (Joint DR Parties), met with Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, in San Francisco.  Also present was Mona Tierney-Lloyd, Senior Director, Western Regulatory Affairs, for EnerNOC.  Myers referred to the Joint DR Parties’ Opening Comments on the Proposed Decision (PD) Adopting 2018 Local and Flexible Capacity Obligations and Refining Resource Adequacy (RA) Program.  Myers indicated that the Joint DR Parties supported certain outcomes reached by the PD. However, Myers advised that the Joint DR Parties remained disappointed that their Phase 3 proposals, in particular, examination of a 2-hour resource qualifying for RA and the unbundling of flexible RA from system and local RA either did not call for direct study by the California Independent System Operator (CAISO) or was not addressed at all. Myers stated that the Joint DR Parties had requested specific modification to the PD to address those concerns.  Tierney-Lloyd indicated that the Joint DR Parties were concerned with the language used in the PD related to a proposal by Southern California Edison Company to count resources that can respond within 20 minutes toward a local capacity RA requirement.  Tierney-Lloyd explained that the issue of the merits of a 20 minute response time for qualifying RA was still being studied, and any action by the Commission that would seem to approve a proposal requiring such a response time was either premature or could prejudge the outcome of that study. Tierney-Lloyd further stated that, to avoid a quotation (from D.16-05-045) at page 22 of the Proposed Decision being taken out of context, that language should be modified to reference the entire discussion on this point.  Tierney-Lloyd identified the Joint DR Parties’ concerns with the CAISO’s efforts to propose changes to the RA Availability Assessment Hours through the CAISO’s Business Practice Management change process in its Proposed Revision Request 986.  Tierney-Lloyd noted that the CAISO indicated that it was going to file a one-time wavier of its tariff for 2018; however, the Joint DR Parties’ concerns remained.

SUMMARY:  On June 21, 2017, Thomas Long, TURN, Legal Director, The Utility Reform Network (TURN), met with Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco.  Also present was Kevin Woodruff, consultant to TURN.  Long and Woodruff referenced TURN’s previously filed June 14, 2017 opening comments on the pending Proposed Decision (PD).  TURN referred to Table 1 of its PD comments, and discussed two corrections to all three methodologies that are needed. The TURN representatives explained the adjustments to the PD’s adopted methodology that are necessary to correct these errors, as shown in Tables 2 and 3 of TURN’s PD comments, and that TURN’s corrections would reduce the cost to ratepayers by $31 million.  The TURN representatives also explained TURN’s position that, if the PD were modified to adopt a different ELCC methodology that yielded higher RA costs, the Commission should phase in 50% of the higher RA requirements in the first year, in order to avoid unnecessarily sudden cost impacts and changes to the RA markets.  The TURN representatives indicated TURN’s support for public reporting of forward procurement data, consistent with confidentiality requirements.  The TURN representatives stated that TURN agrees with the PD’s determination not to adopt a multi-year RA requirement at this time.

SUMMARY:  On June 22, 2017, Thomas Long, TURN, Legal Director, The Utility Reform Network (TURN), had a conference call with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman.  Kevin Woodruff, consultant to TURN, also participated.  Long and Woodruff referenced TURN’s previously filed June 14, 2017 opening comments on the pending Proposed Decision (PD).  TURN referred to Table 1 of its PD comments, and discussed two corrections to all three methodologies that are needed. The TURN representatives explained the adjustments to the PD’s adopted methodology that are necessary to correct these errors, as shown in Tables 2 and 3 of TURN’s PD comments, and that TURN’s corrections would reduce the cost to ratepayers by $31 million.  The TURN representatives also explained TURN’s position that, if the PD were modified to adopt a different ELCC methodology that yielded higher RA costs, the Commission should phase in 50% of the higher RA requirements in the first year, in order to avoid unnecessarily sudden cost impacts and changes to the RA markets.  The TURN representatives indicated TURN’s support for public reporting of forward procurement data, consistent with confidentiality requirements.  The TURN representatives stated that TURN agrees with the PD’s determination not to adopt a multi-year RA requirement at this time.

column5: Center for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Technologies
column6: SUMMARY:  On June 22, 2017, Megan Myers, Attorney for the Center for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Technologies (CEERT), met with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present were James Caldwell, Consultant, and Sara Steck Myers, Attorney, for CEERT.  Myers discussed CEERT’s comments on the Proposed Decision (PD) Adopting Local and Flexible Capacity Obligations for 2018 and Refining the Resource Adequacy Program.  Myers stated that CEERT appreciated the PD taking into consideration of CEERT’s concerns. However, Myers advised that CEERT believes that there are issues that remain that should be addressed as soon as possible – either in this PD or in the next Resource Adequacy (RA) rulemaking.  Caldwell stated that now is the time for RA to move more quickly. Sara Steck Myers stated that the Commission may want to consider having a different RA cycle or issuing a mid-term Decision to ensure that important issues related to needed refinement in the RA process are actually fully addressed, rather than leaving them to the June RA Decision, in which time may not permit their resolution.  Caldwell addressed the lack of transparency with RA.  Caldwell also stated concerns about the fact that the Energy Division’s 2015 RA Report had not been issued until January 2017, and it remains unclear about what resources were used to support which functions.  Caldwell also explained that, as to system RA, phasing in Effective Load Carrying Capacity (ELCC) is a mistake.  Caldwell urged the Commission to move forward now to adopt ELCC without further phasing.  As for flexible RA, Caldwell stated that the current process was not working to ensure procurement of resources that meet a flexible need. Caldwell recommended either dropping the program altogether and relying on energy and ancillary service markets or redefining the flexible RA metric.  Written material (attached to the notice) was used.
Notice of Ex Parte Communication of Advisor.  Jennifer Kalafut, Chief of Staff to Commissioner Peterman, noticed ex parte communication with Independent Energy Producers Association, on June 7, 2017.

SUMMARY:  On June 21, 2017, Thomas Long, TURN, Legal Director, The Utility Reform Network (TURN), met with Candace Morey, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco.  Also present was Kevin Woodruff, consultant to TURN.  Long and Woodruff referenced TURN’s previously filed June 14, 2017 opening comments on the pending Proposed Decision (PD).  TURN referred to Table 1 of its PD comments, and discussed two corrections to all three methodologies that are needed. The TURN representatives explained the adjustments to the PD’s adopted methodology that are necessary to correct these errors, as shown in Tables 2 and 3 of TURN’s PD comments, and that TURN’s corrections would reduce the cost to ratepayers by $31 million.  The TURN representatives also explained TURN’s position that, if the PD were modified to adopt a different ELCC methodology that yielded higher RA costs, the Commission should phase in 50% of the higher RA requirements in the first year, in order to avoid unnecessarily sudden cost impacts and changes to the RA markets.  The TURN representatives indicated TURN’s support for public reporting of forward procurement data, consistent with confidentiality requirements.  The TURN representatives stated that TURN agrees with the PD’s determination not to adopt a multi-year RA requirement at this time.

SUMMARY:  On June 7, 2017, Steven Kelly, Policy Director for the Independent Energy Producers Association (IEP), met with Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco.  Also present was Brian Cragg, outside counsel to IEP.  Kelly noted that the Proposed Decision (PD) again proposed to defer a decision on the issue of a multi-year forward reporting or procurement obligation for Resource Adequacy (RA) capacity.  Kelly explained that resolution of this issue at this time is particularly critical.  Kelly and Cragg described IEP’s proposal to establish a multi-year forward framework for RA capacity.  Kelly observed that the two Energy Division staff reports on RA capacity have been helpful, but they have not been issued regularly and the results are somewhat stale by the time the reports are issued.  Kelly noted that IEP’s multi-year reporting requirement would be integrated with the annual RA capacity showings that load-serving entities already make.  Kelly recommended that the PD should be modified to establish a Phase 4 for this proceeding to complete its evaluation of the multi-year forward proposals by the end of this year.  Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On September 11, 2015, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Waen discussed the history of and potential future for Commission policy reform relating to both the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) and the Cost Allocation Mechanism (CAM).  Waen stated MCE's belief of the continued need for reform to the policies relating to both the PCIA and the CAM. Waen also explained the need for each of the potential areas of PCIA- and CAM-related policy reform that MCE hopes to see scoped within the next Long-Term Procurement Plan proceeding cycle. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On October 29, 2015, Matt Barmack, Director of Market Regulatory Analysis of Calpine Corporation, spoke to the audience, which included Cmmr. Florio, at a roundtable discussion at the joint meeting of the Western Interstate Regional Advisory Body, Committee of Regional Electric Power Cooperation, and the State-Provincial Steering Committee, in San Diego. Also present was Brian Turner, Deputy Executive Director. During the roundtable discussion, Dr. Barmack discussed major policy issues with development of a regional independent system operator.  Dr. Barmack addressed the roles of the Commission and California Independent System Operator (CAISO) in resource planning and procurement as well as resource adequacy. Dr. Barmack also described how the Commission and CAISO share responsibility for the Resource Adequacy program.

SUMMARY: On October 14, 2015, Thomas Doughty, Director of State Regulatory Strategy, the California Independent System Operator Corporation (CAISO), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Sepideh Khosrowjah, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in three separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present was Delphine Hou, External Affairs Manager, CAISO. Doughty provided background information on a proposed revision request (PRR) to the CAISO's Business Practice Manual for Reliability. Doughty explained CAISO submitted this PRR to clarify that demand response resources should be available in 20 minutes to meet reliability standards that require the system operator to return the system to a normal state within 30 minutes after a first contingency. Doughty and Hou explained that the 20-minute standard was developed after the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station  outage. Doughty and Hou clarified the 20-minute response time did not represent a change from past CAISO local technical studies.

SUMMARY:  on April 28, 2015, Yuliya Shmidt, program and project supervisor, the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), with Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, in San Francisco.  
Also present were Radu Ciupagea and Peter Spencer, public utilities analysts, ORA. ORA explained that the Commission's policy oversight of electricity procurement occurs in three different proceedings: the long-term procurement plan proceeding, the resource adequacy proceeding, and the joint-reliability plan proceeding. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.
